A more recent survey showed far less support, but that survey was taken amid the current passionate climate largely propelled by the churches and right to live organisations. That is their right.

I am most concerned about the tone of this debate and the tactics employed by some to get their message through. One submission to me was entitled `Putting people down'. That is a crude portrayal of what should be seen as the right of a person to seek a dignified death, one our medical profession provides in an undignified way by using techniques such as the increased morphine option, which still prolongs and eventually poisons.

Concerns have been expressed by the Aboriginal population in some quarters, particularly the Top End, about the Northern Territory law. Anyone knowing my background understands my long‐term understanding of and commitment to Aboriginal issues in this country, stemming back to my academic studies in the 1970s and my support for the Koori culture. I understand the Aboriginal spirituality as best a non‐Aboriginal can, and I propose to detail my views in the Native Title Amendment Bill debate, in which I will outline how traditional Aboriginal law and beliefs cannot be satisfactorily drafted into white man's law.

So I noted with concern the fears expressed in the Koori community about the euthanasia issue, and I question whether those who have stirred these concerns will be so outspoken in support of traditional Aboriginal spiritualism and the sacred nature of their land when the time comes to debate the Native Title Bill. It is incumbent upon us to educate the Aboriginal population that the legislation is the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act.

The second issue in this debate is states rights. We know the Northern Territory is not a state but now know how close even the Prime Minister concedes it is to statehood. To override the territory's independence is to make a mockery of self‐government. The Commonwealth does have a constitutional right to overturn this Northern Territory legislation, but it has no moral right.
Finally, a word on the role of the media in all this. It must be careful it does not portray the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act as a right to kill act. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Southcott, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak in favour of the bill of the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. I will outline my reasons shortly. Firstly, I say that I am glad that the parliament has been given the opportunity to vote freely according to conscience. I would also like to thank all the people who rang me and wrote to me from around Australia for taking the time to tell me how they feel about this bill. Their contribution has assisted me with my own stance on euthanasia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that some constituents have been frustrated by the fact that this bill will be decided on a conscience vote. In one letter from a constituent, for example, I was asked:

Please explain the justice and even‐handedness of a conscience vote of a small group when the bill itself is aimed at destroying democratically enacted law having the approval of about four out of five Australians and providing only an option which those not in agreement may ignore.

There is no room in a modern democracy for martyrdom. Surely the fate of St Thomas More and others tells us that. But it would be a retrograde step for democracy in this country if the principle of the conscience vote was excised from the parliamentary tradition. From time to time, issues that go to the essence of what it is to be human come before this House. Employed sparingly and sensitively with tolerance from all sides, the conscience vote allows a community such as this parliament to reach a decision free from the constraints of partisanship and prejudice.

Most polls demonstrate clear majority support for the practice of euthanasia, but if majority support should automatically be responded to, then Australian parliaments should also support capital punishment, high levels of tariff protection and an end to Australia's immigration program. I do not support any of those things, and I do not believe that it is possible to support euthanasia after examining the legal, professional and ethical problems that it raises.

I have no doubt that many of the proponents of euthanasia are motivated genuinely by compassion. Some may have witnessed a close friend or relative suffer a painful death, but I believe that what is needed for those who are terminally ill is better palliative care, knowing when to continue or not to continue treatment, and knowing when treatment is unwanted.

One of the difficulties I have with the Northern Territory's Rights of the Terminally Ill Act is that the availability of palliative care services for most territorians is rudimentary at best, and so legalised euthanasia will make unnecessary deaths in the Northern Territory inevitable. Palliative care, used appropriately, can avoid the extreme solution, the absolute solution, the final solution of voluntary euthanasia.

Rod Dent, the son of the late Bob Dent who was the first man to die by legally sanctioned euthanasia, yesterday withdrew his support for the Northern Territory laws when he held a press conference with the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews). Rod Dent is reported as saying that he had changed his mind about the territory legislation after watching a video of his father. It was the son's belief that his father had resorted to euthanasia only after becoming very depressed at the state of palliative care in the medical system. Rod Dent was quoted as saying:

I have decided to support the Andrews Bill because I believe you cannot put in place laws for euthanasia where you do not have a decent palliative care system. I believe that the Northern Territory failed my father by not providing good medical care.
Dr Brian Pollard has said:

It is a shameful parody to portray the modern dilemma about decisions regarding death as a grim choice between intolerable suffering, and its only real alternative of being killed, though one too often sees such a presentation.

In invoking the dedicated work of the pioneer of modern palliative care, Dame Cicely Saunders, Pollard summarises the components of good palliative care as including: control of physical symptoms; emotional support and communication; respecting the patient's wishes; teamwork; and the family.

During my intern year I spent a month or two working in a hospice at one of Adelaide's teaching hospitals. Working with the dying and providing them with adequate palliative care is one of the most emotionally demanding areas in medicine. Having worked in that area, having got up in the middle of the night to certify deaths or to respond to the needs of those who are dying, the idea of physician‐assisted suicide in this sort of setting with the terminally ill is something that makes me deeply uncomfortable at my core.

I recognise palliative care's limitations. Some people have suffering which cannot be relieved by palliative care. This suffering is more commonly emotional rather than physical, and I believe that allowing emotional distress to be a criterion for euthanasia opens the practice to potential abuse which would be undetectable and uncontrollable. It is true that a right to die does exist but, as Dr Pollard wrote in the Medical Journal of Australia in 1993:
An appeal to a right to die is perverted when it is intended to mean a right to be killed as in euthanasia.

Our Western legal tradition provides justice for all and protection for the weakest. The 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights declares that every human being has the inherent right to life. As the member for Menzies has pointed out, the Northern Territory statute removes this protection of the weak and actually selects them as the least protected.

Euthanasia differs from the withdrawal of active treatment in that in the former case death is the intention and death is inevitable. As Dr Pollard stated in the same article in the Medical Journal of Australia, `Prescribing for death would be unlike any other medical action.'

The Northern Territory act changes our concept of medical practice. Will the MIMS drug manual now record one of the clinical uses of thiopentone as being for killing patients? Would a euthanasia practitioner like Dr Nitschke be considered a specialist? Will a royal college of euthanasia practitioners be established? What training is required to perform euthanasia? Do these practitioners need medical insurance, if so, what level of medical insurance do they need? Do they require peer review?

On graduation from medical school I took, as was the tradition, the Geneva Declaration, which was a modified form of the Hippocratic oath. The declaration specifically proscribed medical killing. That declaration is not binding but it has the status of an ethical code.
Hilaire Belloc, who was a Liberal member of the House of Commons at the turn of the century, put it differently in verse when he quoted, of the medical profession in the Victorian era:
Thou shalt not kill; but need'st not strive
Officiously to keep alive.
Medical practice has nothing to do with killing people. Why do you need a doctor to kill? What skill is required there?

It is worth looking at the experience of the Netherlands. Dutch statutes actually outlaw euthanasia but the interpretation of the courts has allowed, under certain conditions, doctors to kill their patients. It has been reported in Holland that the option of euthanasia has developed into an expectation and even an obligation. Even more worrying, due to the common practice of falsifying death certificates, nobody knows the real incidence of euthanasia in the Netherlands.

In 1623, the poet John Donne stressed the necessity of acknowledging death as not just an event for the individual or the immediate family, but rather an event for the community. This is what he said:
Any man's death diminishes me, because I am involved in Mankind
And therefore never send to know for whom the bell tolls; it tolls for thee.
The practice of euthanasia in the Northern Territory affects us all, it affects all Australians. I support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you Mr Deputy Speaker. I rise to express my opposition to what has become known as the Andrews bill. As a member representing Canberra in the Australian Capital Territory I join with most territorial members and senators in opposing the bill. But I want to make it very clear that my opposition is not primarily about state or territory rights. I accept the clear constitutional right of the Commonwealth to act in this matter and if, for example, there was a bill in the territory for proposing capital punishment I would be prepared to support a bill overturning that. So I am not prepared to say that on the basis of the fundamental rights of the territory it is wrong that this matter be handled in this way. My concern is with the merits of the bill, not with the rights of the territory.

SPEECH.PARA: I do wish to address some significant issues about territory rights and their relationship to state rights and the way the parliament is handling this matter, but I do not wish to use that as a cloak behind which I will hide. My opposition is based primarily on my concern and my views about active voluntarily euthanasia. On balance I have come to the view that I support active voluntary euthanasia and legislation properly constructed and properly determined by democratically elected parliaments to establish that right. I support that and I have told my constituents so.

As the previous speaker in this debate has had, I have had a number of letters from constituents on both sides of the debate, and I have felt an obligation to write back to them. Of course, it was very easy to write back to those who were writing to urge me to do what I intended to do anyway. It is always very easy to respond to such letters. But a substantial number of intelligent, concerned members of my constituency have written thoughtful letters expressing views opposite to those which I hold. I try to respond on every matter, but we all know the flow of correspondence we get. But it seemed to me that, in a matter as fundamental as this, a matter where the decision is an individual one for each member, it was particularly appropriate that I wrote back to my constituents, not only saying what I intended to do but also briefly saying why.

For those who wished to seek it in detail, I indicated that the way to see this would be by reading what I said in the Hansard; but in those letters I said that, as a general principle, my view is that informed adults should have the right to make the decision about ending their lives as a matter of free choice, in circumstances of great pain and suffering. I do not pretend that that was a comprehensive analysis of the philosophical issues associated with active voluntary euthanasia and with this bill, but it was intended to go to the core of the argument and to the core element in the debate, which has convinced me to take the course of action which I am taking, and I felt I should at least put to my constituents a clear indication of the nature of my thinking on this matter.

Always, when we address issues to do with legalisation and the provision of a legal framework for controversial matters which we all know are taking place in our society but about which many people have concerns, one argument which is put and which has validity is that it is better to have legislative safeguards around what is currently an informal practice exercised at the discretion, in this instance, of certain medical practitioners. The surveys indicate how prevalent the practice of active voluntary euthanasia is.

I have to say that, if your view is that euthanasia is immoral or wrong, then the fact that it happens is not a satisfactory argument for the provision of a legislative framework; but, if you recognise—and some people do so more unequivocally than I on this matter—on balance, the legitimacy of the argument for active voluntary euthanasia, it is much better to have a transparent scheme with strong safeguards rather than to allow the current informal arrangements to continue.

BREAK.PARA: In the time available, let me turn to the four points that have particularly convinced me that I should support active voluntary euthanasia and therefore oppose this bill. The first point goes to the autonomy of the individual: a fundamental principle of liberal democracy that, as far as possible, the state should provide autonomy to the individual to determine his or her decisions with regard to their life.

The second point is the issue of equity of access. I do not have time, in the 10 minutes allowed me, to deal with this issue in the way I would like to, but I am concerned—in this, as in other debates—that, where we maintain the facade that something does not happen in our society, the wealthy and the powerful get access to proper medical assistance, whilst those who do not have the influence or the financial capacity to get access to this properly illegal exercise are disadvantaged. The argument has been put eloquently by others; I simply reiterate my concern because I do not have time to go into it in detail.

The third point goes to the question of certainty, so that people can know their rights and not simply gain access to active voluntary euthanasia through good fortune because of the views of the doctor by whom they are being treated. The fourth point concerns empowerment and the transfer from doctors to patients of the power to make decisions with regard to this matter.

I want to take some time to speak briefly about the territory rights issue to which I referred briefly initially. As I said at that time, I do not regard the territory rights question as paramount, but it is a significant subsidiary matter in dealing with this bill. I recognise the right of the Commonwealth to determine the form of self‐government, to legislate directly for that, and to set the parameters within which the territories govern themselves. I also recognise the right of the Commonwealth to legislate in any matter in the territory as specified in the constitution. But I think that it is not appropriate and not good practice for the Commonwealth, having given legislative authority to a territorial parliament, to seek to micro‐manage what has been transferred and to say, `We gave you the power to do this, but we don't like the way you have done it.'

I have never been a great advocate of states rights, any more than I am now an advocate of territory rights. I have always been one with a greater concern about people's rights. It does stick in one's throat, however, to find many of the greatest advocates of states rights so enthusiastically supporting this piece of legislation when they know that the Commonwealth could not act in that way with regard to their states and almost certainly they would not support the Commonwealth doing so if it could. I find that hypocritical in the extreme, but I do not intend to take the opposite tack myself and, having recognised the right of the Commonwealth to override states where it has the constitutional right to do so, deny its right to do so with regard to the territory.

But the legislation does have implications in the territories beyond its immediate intention. I am concerned about the uncertainty created and the implications for other areas of policy, such as the Medical Treatment Act 1994 of the ACT. My concern is that the objectives of the bill are wrong and that it is being poorly pursued.

To sum up, I would like to refer to some comments made by a former Liberal senator, the then Senator Peter Baume, now Professor Peter Baume, who, in a recent Lionel Murphy Memorial Lecture, referred to the need for good quality palliative care to be available to all who require it, and acknowledged that it is not available at the present time. He went on to say:

The capacity to control symptoms, called palliative care, is progressing quickly. But even the best palliative care will not help everyone. There will be some people whose symptoms and distress continue, whose suffering is unrelieved, and who are condemned, as the law stands now, to suffer and to endure until they are lucky enough to die. . . There are occasions when people wish to die, when people have had enough, when people of sound mind wish to avoid a future which offers only suffering and grief. That we forbid an adequate response to every such person is an indictment upon us and upon our social arrangements.
For those reasons, I oppose the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forrest, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate an opportunity to place my sentiments on this matter on the public record. Like many of the other speakers and the previous speaker, I have received many letters on both sides of the debate which have caused me to wrestle with my own conscience. I think that I need to say from the outset that I support the bill based upon my philosophy and my opposition to euthanasia.

SPEECH.PARA: But that is not to say that I have not listened intently to the debate that has gone on around this place. It has been quite refreshing, actually, to listen to speakers who have different perspectives on this matter because there are, in fact, two principles that we have been wrestling with. One is an issue of conscience in respect to our individual positions on euthanasia, and the other is an important pillar, too, which is the perceived rights of one parliament to make its own law without interference from another parliament. I have listened intently to the contributions, particularly on the second of those matters, but my conclusion is to continue with my support of the bill on the principle of my opposition to euthanasia.

For the benefit of those people who have written to me, I would like to place on the public record my own experiences with close family members, close friends and their families as they have confronted the challenge of dying. There have been three occasions which have left a permanent impression on me about the challenge that people are confronted with, which we will all one day inevitably be confronted with, as to how we handle death.

The first of these occasions was the death of my brother‐in‐law, Mr Neville Chapman, who was a much loved member of our family. I have two natural brothers, but Neville was not just my sister's husband, he was, indeed, an additional brother. We cherish the memory of him. He had a terminal illness—a tumour—and, after several operations, he expressed the wish to pass on. It was a long and torturous time for our family, but on the night that Neville passed away we were all there—friends and family—and I would not have wanted to have been cheated from the experience of assisting Neville to go on to another world, as he referred to it.

He was supported by nursing staff at home and he died in the comfort of his own home. On the night he died, 25 family and friends were gathered in the room. Neville was in and out of a coma, but when he was conscious he expressed his will to pass on. The day before that, he was quite upset. There was a member of our family that he had had a confrontation with and he expressed a desire to meet with her and settle the matter. That was done. We arranged that and, between the two of them, they resolved their conflict. Neville's conscience was appeased on the matter.

When the doctor made his last attendances, I asked him, `How much longer?' He said, `I've just administered a massive dose of medication that to a normal person would be fatal, but he is comfortable and he is not in pain. I suggest that you all say goodbye.' We did that progressively, one by one.

BREAK.PARA: One of the members of our group, somewhat reservedly, sat at the rear of the bedroom where Neville was. I said to him, `You need to say goodbye to Neville, he wants to go on.' Immediately upon his saying goodbye, Neville passed away. It was a beautiful experience for our whole family and one which we treasure. It was of great assistance to us in managing our own grief at the loss of someone we considered so precious.

I would not have wanted us to have been cheated of that opportunity as a family. As we shared together the experience, we were all confronted with what I think members of the parliament have been confronted with, which is the challenge of how we would have managed that situation if it were us lying there, helpless and dependent. This is really what confronts us all in terms of where we stand on the philosophical principle of allowing people to take their own lives.

The second occasion was with my father, a man for whom I have great love. He was a stroke patient who spent the last two years of his life wrestling with his rehabilitation. He finally expressed the desire to die—he had had enough. I have heard many contributions on this topic along these lines where someone is lying there helplessly and they have had enough and want to pass on.

In fact, on one Saturday afternoon that I spent with my father in the nursing home where he was bedridden, he actually asked me if I could do it. It is a great shock to a son to have his father ask him to put him away. After I had recovered—I had to leave the room—I asked my father, `How would you suggest we did this, Dad?' He said, `Well, you could simply smother me, son. You have two brothers, but I am asking you because I know you would have the courage to do it.' Even in that situation, I said to my father, `Dad, do not be frightened of dying. It is an experience that we will all be here to share with you.'

I was able to make the contribution because of the previous experience with my brother-in‐law. We were all there again for the passing of my father—again, a precious experience that the family shared. On many occasions I asked my father, `Are you uncomfortable? Are you in pain?' and he always said, `No, I just wish it would hurry up.' I just want these expressions of sentiment on the public record because I do not think people are conscious of the fact that death is part of life's experience; it is part of a family's experience. As distressing as it can be, it can be a beautiful experience. Those two occasions I count as being the two most significant experiences of my own life. I know I will carry them to my own deathbed.

I remember saying to my father—by this stage he was unconscious—he was wrestling and quite unsettled and I simply whispered in his ear and said, `Dad, just do as you are being instructed.' I do not know what a death experience will be, but clearly my father was being challenged in some way and I said, `Just do as you are instructed.' Within seconds he passed away. It was a precious and beautiful experience that I was there for his last challenge.

The third occasion was a good friend and mentor. On this occasion, cancer of the kidney and liver saw him substantially debilitated. Watching him pass through that demise with his family was very distressing. On many occasions I asked him—and I checked with the palliative care support—`Are you in pain?' and he said, `No, I'm just waiting quietly to pass on to a better world.' On that particular occasion, I stood more to the rear as that family went through the same experience that I had had myself. I think it is part of the management of grief for all of us. To be cheated of that and have that replaced by some clinical procedure I think denies the community and families the opportunity to share in the whole experience, and thereby equip themselves for when they confront the same challenge.

I am supporting the bill. I regret that this causes me to forsake another principle which I hold dear, and that is the rights that are in our constitution of parliaments of the states. Even recognising that the Northern Territory is not yet a state, I know it does aspire to that position. I have to try and reconcile myself in terms of the significant impact this legislation in the Northern Territory has on the whole nation. I feel that the greater majority of the nation has been denied an opportunity to put its point of view. I believe that is what this parliament is doing as we debate this bill and I am therefore supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellis, Annette, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This is probably one of the most difficult debates that members of this House need to participate in but it is one that we have been presented with and therefore have to deal with. It is true to say—and I think everybody in this particular chamber and in the other chamber will agree—that, given the nature of the debate and given the lobbying that has gone on for every member since this debate has come up, probably every emotion that surrounds the question of euthanasia has been provoked in each of us. There has been a lot of evidence given by other members of personal experiences. I could do that as well but I am not going to. The reason I am not is that every other member of the population who needs to face this question does not have that ability and so I do not believe that I should.

SPEECH.PARA: I have done my own straw polls in the community—at dinner tables and at community functions—and I have yet to find an overwhelming majority or, in fact, any majority that agrees that we should stop this bill. I have had people of the Catholic faith, and I am not Catholic, people of all faiths and people of no faith at all overwhelmingly say to me that they should have the ability to make their own choice in this particular decision.

I want to touch briefly on the position of the territory governments. I think I am a little unique in this place—certainly, I do not know of anyone else in the House—in that, until recently, I was a member of the ACT Legislative Assembly. As a member of the ACT assembly, I watched very carefully the evolution of self‐government. I know that Mr Andrews, in bringing this bill forward, is doing so within the rights of the constitution. However, he is only able to do so because it is a territory that has made this decision and not a state. Now, I find that very difficult. I find it a bit indulgent that he can do it because a territory has made the rule but if a state had made the rule he could not do it. If a state had made the rule, where would we be with this particular debate?

I have seen at very close hand the decisions that have been gone through within the ACT on self‐government. I understand very clearly the difficulties that our community has gone through, and is still going through, to a minor degree, in growing into self‐determination but I believe very strongly in that democratic process. It is interesting to note that this particular question of euthanasia, in a slightly different form, has twice come before the ACT Legislative Assembly in its very short life, since 1989. On both occasions, the ACT parliament determined to revoke that particular suggestion.

It has happened differently in the Northern Territory but, as with the ACT, we have seen the local democratic process evolve. As a previous member of that level of government in the ACT, I am compelled by my own belief in that process to enforce that process. I believe very much that the people of the ACT, through their government and their parliament, have a right to determine how they feel about this issue. As I have said, the ACT government has looked at it twice and refused it twice. The Northern Territory government has looked at it and it has adopted it. So be it.

BREAK.PARA: On the question of euthanasia itself, I think it is a personal issue. It is personal to the point that I do not think I should stop others if they wish to adopt that view but I am not advocating it either. In fact, I do not know whether I would go down the track of euthanasia in my own instance. I think I would make up my mind on that question at the time I needed to but I think I should have the right to make that choice at that time. There are people in the community who are enormously opposed to euthanasia and there are people who very strongly support it. I do not think, as an individual parliamentarian, it is my right to stop people from having the choice.

It is obvious that I am not coming from a religious background. I am coming from a purely human rights point of view, and that is that I am not going to impose my wishes on other people in my community. In an ideal world, people could be in a position to go down the path that was suggested by the previous speaker, but it is not an ideal world and there are people who may make the decision that they wish to take the euthanasia path. If they do, and they feel strongly and independently about that, I do not think I have the right to stand in their way and say, `Because of how I feel, you cannot do this.'

I know there are huge difficulties in trying to legislate for this sort of social policy. I understand all of those difficulties but I also think that, if we are going to have this debate, we have to be pretty honest about it, and I am not for one moment implying that other members are not being honest. I am being as honest as I can be in what I think is a very difficult situation.

I am a very strong supporter of the palliative care process. I belong to the local association, I have my own personal experience in relation to it, and I will continue to support the expenditure of funds, both government and non‐government, on those services; but I am not in a position where I believe that I can vote for the Andrews bill. I am going to vote against the bill, and I am going to do it for all of the reasons that I hope I have explained as well as I can here today.

When you look at the democratic process of the two territory governments we have in this country, and you see that one has gone one way and one has gone the other, they have to be answerable to their own communities, and that is the way it ought to be, despite the fact that it is correct in terms of the constitution. But if we are going to give these people self‐determination, we have to allow them to do it.

As I said, in relation to the personal issue, it is just that: personal. It is so personal that I refuse to stop those who wish to do it from doing it. By the same token, I am not advocating euthanasia for everybody. I am saying that, where people have strong opposition to it, they simply must understand that others have a strong view for it, and that we must therefore let the individual decide. If society in the two territories to date—but we are talking particularly about the Northern Territory—has made a decision through the democratic process that people have this right, then allow them to exercise it. For those in the community in the Northern Territory who do not wish to participate in the euthanasia process, fine; nobody is making them. But for those who wish to exercise their right under that legislation, we must allow them to do so.

Mr MILES (Braddon—Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (11.17 a.m.)—I rise to state that I support the Euthanasia Laws Bill which is being brought in by Kevin Andrews. I want to make a few comments about it. I acknowledge the sensitivity of the member for Namadgi (Ms Ellis) in talking about this. It is an issue of emotion and complexity which requires all of us to really examine our role as members of parliament and also to reflect on the great diversity and range of emotions in regard to this whole issue, and to try to do that in a compassionate, sensitive way.

It is great that we have got a debate such as this, as it allows everybody to have a conscience discussion in this House, and it is refreshing to be able to have that opportunity in the parliament to talk about fundamental issues like this without the restraints of party discipline and so on, and for all of us to be able to express our views. I am not sure how many members have gone before those of us who are now speaking on this bill, but I wonder whether there is anything more to be said, really. But a responsibility which we have is to share our ideas on the floor of this House in regard to how we see the complexities of this issue.

I want to begin by saying that, as a young boy, I grew up with an elderly grandfather, who was part of our family. In regard to this issue, my thoughts are certainly moulded by my life experiences of living with an elderly grandfather who was a great person to have in the house while I was just a boy growing up. When it comes to the issue of euthanasia, having the right, as provided for in the Northern Territory legislation, does create new pressures of possibilities on people as they go into that age and phase of life.

I certainly would never have wanted, nor do I want, a situation where people who have poured out their heart and their love and their life for other people around them get to a stage where they feel that they are a burden and that if they moved on in life the family may be better off. They may be able to hand on assets or some financial reserves or something which they may have. They might feel that because of the pressures that just happen to exist on the family around them, the best thing for them would be to undertake the euthanasia option and therefore pass on. I think that that is a pressure that ought not ever be considered. No person as they come to that phase of life should ever have those thoughts become part of their thinking. That is one of the reasons for which I support this legislation brought in by Kevin Andrews.

The second point is that the legalisation of euthanasia also introduces uncertainties into the clear prohibition of intentional killing, which is the foundation of all civil rights. When we talk about civil rights in our western traditions in the world, one of the things which is fundamental to that is that there should be no intentional killing. In actual fact, it does raise the question as to whether by having the right to die you actually undermine the right to live, as a concept. I have not explored that philosophically to any great extent but I suspect, in working through that issue, that if you do bring into the legal structures of our society the right to die, you are also taking away from it the concept of the right to live. I think that is an area which we need to explore a little more.

Thirdly, I think that people often give compassionate motives for speaking in favour of euthanasia. I think that is very genuine and I understand that and I can see that that is a valid point to put. It is very valid, I think. However, in a matter which is so individually complex as dying, it is impossible for anyone, including the sufferers themselves I might say, to determine artificially the balance of factors which would support the deliberate taking of life. Once you try to legalise these things, you would have to try to determine the balance of what you weigh up and what should be done and how this should be undertaken. Yet there is a huge diversity of emotions, of love and compassion, which is involved at this stage in life with people. Inevitably, what happens, because we try to work out how and under what restrictions this should happen, is it becomes an artificial sort of formula on how it should be able to be undertaken. I do not think that that has the capacity to provide for the great diversity of circumstances that exist.

I do not believe that we should weaken the clear existing legal prohibitions against deliberate killing. To do so will only increase the vulnerability, I believe, of the dying. Doctors do not now want, and must not be given the responsibility for, deliberately ending the life of a patient. To do so, I believe, would increase the power of the doctor over a patient to an extent that would distort the relationship between them.

Finally, on those points, it is not possible to secure limits to euthanasia. Once we start down that road I think it opens the door. Already there is a steady increase in reports of the practice in the Netherlands where the legal barriers to deliberate killing have been compromised, and I think we would find the same in our community if we did the same.

I think that our position in this parliament ought to be to oppose the situation in the Northern Territory and to support the Kevin Andrews bill. I go back again to the fact that for me, placing pressure on people, particularly as they get on in life, to start thinking of the options—that they would be better off passing on than actually staying—is totally untenable. I am sure that that would happen and it would be very unfavourable in our society and community. I think that our duty in these circumstances is to provide care and sustenance, socially and spiritually, at this stage for any of our brothers and sisters within our community, so that they are provided for and given the care that a person at that stage of life should have and should be able to expect.

The last thing I want to say is that I think this does open up the possibility that younger people, of 20 years of age or so, might say, `I am really depressed. I am having a lot of difficulties.' They might go to doctors and be able to get an option of taking their lives early. I do not think that we should be opening it up in that sort of sense at all. That would be a real concern to me. People are often very stable, but if sometimes they start to show that they are depressed—it might only be for a month or two—this also opens up the possibility that not only could it happen with elderly folk, but also it could become an option for a younger person. A younger person might say, `I am happy that I have lived for 20 years. I now want to take my own life.' I think that that would be tragic. I support the bill brought into the House by Kevin Andrews.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis, Arch, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This issue before us today is a matter of deep conscience to all members of the parliament and, I think, to any decent human being who gives it any more than cursory thought. Every member of the parliament has listened to the views expressed not just here in the parliament, but throughout the Australian community. I have listened carefully to the debate. I know some members have referred to opinion polls as a basis upon which they think the matter should be determined. Others have referred to the constituent mail and the contact they have had. Some claim to be casting a vote which reflects the majority view of their electorates. I do not think that anyone can genuinely know the actual views of the 82,000 or so constituents in their electorate on a matter of such intense personal feeling. At the end of the day, I think that we have to vote as our consciences dictate. That is exactly what I will be doing. I do not pretend to be able to represent anyone else's conscience in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I also wish to place on the record that the question of the states or the territories rights does not move me in this debate. Human rights are far more important and, as other speakers have indicated, I would be quite happy to exercise a vote to overturn state or territory laws that I felt strongly about. This bill and the Northern Territory legislation means what it says—the thin end of the wedge argument also does not move me. People who have claimed the Northern Territory legislation produces outcomes that it does not, do not do their cause any good whatsoever. It does nothing of the sort and, were it to be so, I think that you would find a unanimous attitude within the federal parliament. So those who have adopted a scare campaign approach to this have done themselves and their cause no good.

Let me turn now to the substance of the issue, which is voluntary euthanasia. The active intervention by doctors to end the life of terminally ill patients who are suffering extreme physical and mental pain has been practised in Australia for years. Doctors have publicly admitted that the practice exists. This has been so without the Northern Territory legislation and it would continue to be so if the Northern Territory legislation were struck down.

The bill is, therefore, not about whether there will be active euthanasia. It is about whether there should be some rules laid down by the community about the circumstances in which it is legal, and whether there should be safeguards and rights for those contemplating euthanasia. Indeed, it seems to me that the Northern Territory laws make the unauthorised euthanasia practised by one doctor in isolation from other medical practitioners less likely, rather than more likely.

As have many others, I have watched as family members or close friends have suffered the agony associated with some terminal illnesses. One person underwent an operation for a brain tumour, resulting in her being a bed‐bound vegetable with virtually no motor control and deteriorating general health. After some months, her very loving husband told close relatives in the family that they might like to call around one afternoon because the family doctor—who was himself a very close family friend and was a regular at family Christmas lunches and New Year functions—would be calling the next day. That next day was the last day of her life. That was about 35 years ago.

Another was a person who, after years of pain and illness, relied on regular blood transfusions and hospital visits to stay alive. I well recall him asking me recently to accompany him to his doctor so that he could have his new will completed. He rejected his scheduled blood transfusion and instead went away for a few days to the Sunshine Coast. He became ill at the beach, away from his family and away from his doctor, and he did not recover.

If the Northern Territory laws were available to such people, would they have used them? Probably; but who really knows? Should I now vote to deny others in these or similar circumstances the opportunity to choose a dignified way to seek medical help to end their life, subject to the safeguards that are contained in the Northern Territory laws? My answer to that is no. The Northern Territory law provides for three doctors, including a psychiatrist, to agree on the appropriateness of euthanasia in every case. It provides for waiting periods. It provides for informed consent. And it only applies in the Northern Territory. People in any other part of Australia are not subject to any part of the law. You would have to shift to the Northern Territory if you wished to avail yourself of the voluntary euthanasia law.

During the course of the debate, both in the parliament and in the community, I have heard fears and claims of what it could do to young people and to people who, without their knowledge, would be victims of `involuntary' euthanasia. There is a view in the community that, because the national parliament is discussing this, it will have national implications: that is, that there will be a national voluntary euthanasia code. That is simply not the case. None of those things apply. The legislation does not affect the people in the state of Queensland as a law, nor does it affect the people in any other part of the country outside the Northern Territory. The bill is not legislating nationally for the availability of voluntary euthanasia. This debate is a consideration of whether the Northern Territory legislation should be allowed to stand, or whether we should exercise our power and rights as a national parliament to overturn those laws.

It is also important to recognise that doctors themselves have expressed strong concerns about participating in euthanasia. I fully understand that view and I support the right of any doctor to refuse to be involved in any aspect of voluntary euthanasia. That is a very proper exercise of their conscience, and there is nothing that I know of that would force them to do otherwise.

A lot has been said about the circumstances of what I understand to be the only legal act of euthanasia that has been committed, the case of Bob Dent. I do not wish to traverse the events of the last 24 hours. But I do want to remind the House and to place on the record some of the comments that Bob Dent made when he wrote the letter which he sought to make public. He said:
There is now a constant fear of a fall, which could cause terrible injury to my fragile bones. I cannot even get a hug, in case my ribs crack.

My own pain is made worse by watching my wife suffering as she cares for me: bathing and drying me, cleaning up after my `accidents' in the middle of the night and watching my body fade away. If I were to keep a pet animal in the same condition I am in, I would be prosecuted.

That has raised, quite properly, the matter of palliative care. Irrespective of one's view on the question of voluntary euthanasia or this bill before the parliament, all members would support improved palliative care services. Irrespective of the outcome of the vote on this matter, I do hope that one of the positive outcomes of this debate is that there will be, across all parties, a commitment to see an increase in palliative care services, their availability and the quality of palliative care. I believe that the current budget actually reduces the funding to palliative care. I do not want to make a point about that, but I do think that arising out of this may come a focus on the community obligation to palliative care, which probably has not been given the priority it deserves over the years. It is something that I would urge all members of parliament in all parties to take up.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly has twice considered this law. There is a clear will of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly to have voluntary euthanasia available to their citizens. I believe they have carefully considered these issues which are before us today. They have arrived at a conclusion which I believe is a reasonable one. I will not vote to overturn their law. I will be voting against this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have chosen to speak today in support of the private member's bill introduced by Mr Andrews, the member for Menzies. Its purpose is to overturn what I consider to be an unrepresentative law which affects all Australians and was recently passed by the Northern Territory legislature.

SPEECH.PARA: This is amongst the most important legislation to come before the parliament during this government's tenure and I am aware of the many arguments put on both sides of the debate. But, in particular, I must say that I am appalled that the government has chosen to reduce the standing of this bill by referring it to this Main Committee. As stated before, I am utterly opposed to being pushed into the Main Committee to conduct a debate on behalf of my constituents on one of the most controversial pieces of legislation to come before this parliament this year.

Now that I am able to participate and contribute, I want to make it perfectly clear from the start that I do not think that anyone can do better than to start from the same place that the member for Menzies did by identifying the key falsehoods being spread in this debate.

First of all, this is not a debate about state or territory rights. This is not a debate about the separation of church and state, nor about imposing religious values on others. This is not about regulating current practice and this is not a simple issue of personal autonomy. This is plainly and simply about whether or not the government should have the authority to legislate for the death of its own citizens.

Some people like to believe that this is legislation that gives terminally ill people the right to choose a swift and dignified end and that it can be managed by legislation. All we need to do is provide a set of adequate controls and everything will be all right. This is just not true and I intend, today, to concentrate my part of this debate speaking to this fallacy.

Before I do, I would just like to spend a couple of minutes spelling out the key untruths that some commentators have said euthanasia is about. The first is about state or territory rights. It has been stated that territories, by their nature, do not have rights in this issue, but rather obligations. The constitution is quite clear on their position. Good government in this country does not allow us to be selective about which parts of the constitution we wish to follow. Even if it did, this is a law that does not just affect territorians and cannot be left to territorians and their government alone. All Australians who meet the criteria of the territorial law can apply. It is a law that has been passed by a small majority of a small legislature. It is not representative of the nation's view, otherwise similar legislation would be either debated or enacted in all parts of the states and territories of the Commonwealth of Australia.

If the people of the Northern Territory are deemed to have such an informed and important electoral voice in this nation then I ask the question that should be put to the other premiers that supported the Northern Territory Chief Minister: why do they not allow the Northern Territory to become a state and give them the full representation in the Senate that statehood would give them? Of course they will not do that and they have dragged their heels on this matter for a long time. I have not heard yet that this ought to take place as part of this debate.

This is not about the separation of church and state, nor about imposing religious values on others. There are many who find it convenient to criticise people who oppose euthanasia as being dominated by the church and trying to impose religious views on others. I find this cynical and dishonest, as many of the same critics are prepared to leave care for the sick, the homeless and the disabled to the same churches who minister, aid, support and provide counselling to many in need. It is illogical that the church should then be denied a voice in life and death issues that face people who rely on them for care. The fact is that the church represents a constituency which has a legitimate right to raise a voice which in any case, in this particular instance, is supported by many non‐religious people who have raised similar concerns regarding this legislation.

This territorial law devalues people and can make them feel as if they are a burden. It can promote a suicide mentality which must be worrisome for a country that has one of the highest youth suicide levels in the developed world and, I might add, that in the case of senior citizens has a suicide rate for male persons twice that of female persons. This is not about regulating current practice; what currently goes on will continue. People will be able to choose not to receive treatment that will prolong life, and suggesting that it will not is just a fallacy. It is a fundamental human right to reject medical attention. There is no obligation on anybody to accept medical attention.

Suggesting current practice is not adequate to meet a patient's needs is avoiding the truth. Switching off life support or continuing palliative care will continue to be a choice. This law does not mean that people living outside the Northern Territory will no longer be able to access treatments available. So why must we accept changes to the laws there? This is not a simple issue of personal autonomy. This is an area where most people can identify with the feeling that there is a right of choice—and one of the most fundamental. Pro‐choice has been a label and a symbol applied also in the abortion debate, but in that case the choice is not made by the life about to be extinguished. In this debate, however, all life must be regarded as fundamentally precious, as is not the case in the other debate.

I am concerned that this belief in the right of choice is one of the least understood. People who qualify for euthanasia under the Northern Territory act will be under enormous stress and quite significant external influences. Men and women who know that their lifetimes will have shortened, finite limits may feel that there is no reason to prolong the inevitable. This may be emphasised by physical pain, reduced control of bodily functions, or simply feeling that they have become a burden to others. Human nature is such that a decision on one day of depression can easily be the opposite of one made on another day. The safeguards put in place by the Territory's legislation are totally inadequate to protect in these circumstances.

I fear that, if euthanasia were to become a commonplace thing, for some people the decision to die would almost be viewed as a duty. I put it to some of the people who perhaps support the user‐pays concept as part of public policy: think carefully. We have a system where we provide fair assistance to those who need it—and that ranges all the way to quite old age. Once you apply a regime where some people are considered to be less important than others in terms of their lives, the next step along the track is to start to make the same distinguishing policy decisions in relation to their rights to receive medical attention, medical resources or, for that matter, the other ranges of resources we extend to them by virtue of our system of fair and equal treatment of all citizens in this country. If that happens, people in that position may well, in the future, come to be seen as having a less important requirement for these resources or for care to be extended to them.

Let me make one observation in the very brief opportunity I have in 10 minutes in this place. Consider carefully this: we have a system of health insurance, both public and private, that is community rated—in other words, there is no risk rating. It is not a quantum leap in logic to suggest that, once you accept that euthanasia is a commonplace part of our society, one of the first things that will be challenged in the long run on the question of resource allocation will be community rating of health insurance. In my view, that will be a black day, and I believe that the Northern Territory legislation is pushing us towards that inevitable destination where we consider some people as being less important than others in terms of their lives.

The territory safeguards are totally inadequate. Without a positive request from a patient made at a moment before execution of the euthanasia process, we slide into a situation of proxy permission being given for people to be killed with the permission of the state. In the remaining time I have, I just want to emphasise this particular point. We have seen already a situation where a lady in an unfortunate position in Tasmania is applying to avail herself of the Northern Territory's legislation. She is, I believe, a quadriplegic. In this particular instance, she feels that her quality of life is so diminished that she wishes to end her life.

This then brings us into the whole question of how these safeguards will apply. What age limit, for instance, will be considered to be the minimum? What, for instance, is going to be the situation in relation to unsoundness of mind? To be unsound of mind in a traditional legal sense has meant that a person would need to be so severely affected by mental illness, or a similar factor, as to be incapable of managing his or her own financial personal affairs. I understand that in the Netherlands, for instance, there have been instances where euthanasia has been made available to those who are in such an unsound state of mind because of their financial and other pressures in relation to their day‐to‐day lives.

I would just like to reiterate the outrage I feel at being obliged to speak for only 10 minutes in this secondary chamber on such an important piece of legislation. It is a disgrace, and I would like to urge government members to consider this. Here I am, 10 minutes have expired in such a short time. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that many in this place will, of course, have a very clear‐cut view of where they stand on this issue. But I think there are a great number of us who have not found it an easy decision, and have not always found a number of the issues particularly clear. The arguments have often been clouded by suggestions about states rights and political concerns, and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not just a social issue that we are addressing. It is for many a very personal debate as well. There has been a lot of emotional and emotive argument, and I think that it is one that people find it very hard to be objective about, quite frankly, because we are all, of course, conditioned by our past experiences—and sometimes by very deep personal experiences—in this whole area.

I think that it is a decision that no member of this parliament is taking lightly or easily because, apart from being conscious of the issue per se, many members have been aware of the pressures within their constituency and that, whatever they do, they are going to upset a lot of people one way or the other. The decision we take now, it seems to me, is one that is very similar to the choice that the doctors will make under the Northern Territory legislation when they make that actual decision to assist someone to die. If we vote for euthanasia, we are indirectly assisting that process, and if we vote no, we are denying people that option.

Like most other members, I suspect, I have received a lot of lobbying on this issue. I have had a lot of letters and correspondence; very few, I would have to say, from within my own electorate. The vast majority, by a factor of 10 or 20 to one, have come from outside my electorate. Those from within my electorate have been a mere couple of handfuls, to be honest. But I have talked with a lot of people around my electorate and I have found that, when talking to people, there seems to be a different view from the quite obviously orchestrated letter writing campaigns. Like many other members, I have read lengthy tomes on the arguments on both sides. I have read articles, I have listened to Marshall Perron, and I have talked with Kevin Andrews and others. I have been lobbied personally, and sometimes there have been some very personal and heart‐rending letters, both for and against euthanasia. I have also had some pretty strident and graphically threatening letters about how I should vote and I have even been accused that, if I vote the wrong way, I would have blood on my hands.

The churches, of course, have been very active and opinion polls have been talked about by many. It seems to me that the problem with the opinion polls, although they are fairly clear‐ cut as I read them, is that, firstly, you have got to get the question right and, secondly, and probably more importantly, before the general population can answer an opinion poll they need to actually understand what they are talking about in terms of what is euthanasia. I think a lot of people confuse euthanasia with just turning off life support systems, which is not what we are talking about today.

Let me make a couple of points very clear. It is a pity the previous speaker, the member for Moore (Mr Filing) has departed, because I would agree with him to the extent that I think this should have been a debate that took place in the main chamber. I think we all should have had equal time. In this debate, above all, nobody speaks as a minister. We all speak as private members; we should have all been treated equally, in my view.

Having said that, I will deal with another issue, as well, in terms of states rights. I notice that present in the chamber is the honourable gentleman from the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas). I have to say to him—and others who have the view—that I do not believe that states rights is an issue that clouds my judgment on this particular issue. Clearly, the territory is a territory and the Commonwealth has the right to overturn legislation of the territory.

But, frankly, even if you take the view that the territory is almost a state, it seems to me that there are occasions when the national parliament must take a national stand on some issues. My judgment today is not based in any way on the states rights issue and I have to make that very clear.

I have to say also, though, that from the beginning I have leaned towards supporting euthanasia, but I have had concerns about the safeguards. Once the principle has been accepted, or become law, then of course it can be open to misuse and that is a concern.

If this bill, the Andrews bill, is passed—and we all know, of course, that euthanasia is practised covertly—what happens to the doctors who are currently covertly assisting people to die? Do they suddenly stop doing that? I very much doubt it. Much has been said about Holland and abuses. I do not understand why, if it is so terrible in that country, that country continues to practise it. There have been many extrapolations about abortion and I am not going to get into that today. We have been regaled from both sides of the argument with all sorts of information about safeguards and there is the Dondas chart, which I was appreciative of reading and working my way through.

We have heard arguments about pressures on the elderly. Experience tells me that, whatever we do in terms of legislation, it is hard to legislate perfectly. My own experience is largely conditioned, obviously, by personal experience. My mother died of cancer a couple of years ago; she received outstanding hospice care—outstanding palliative care. It was overseas but, nevertheless, it was outstanding care and I am not suggesting that she in any way would have sought euthanasia under the legislation we are talking about. But it is not always available and then, of course, it is not always enough and I understand that the Northern Territory has, in fact, upgraded its palliative care program significantly.

Euthanasia is happening now and it seems to me that we need to bring the matter under control. Let us be clear: voluntary euthanasia is not about turning off life support systems; it is a very conscious and deliberate act. We are talking about the deliberate act of a person to take a decision about themselves for themselves. And the bottom line, for me, is a matter of choice and the right to die with dignity. If someone gets to the point of losing all human dignity and the brain may be functioning fine but the bodily functions are not, then I believe that in those limited cases there needs to be a legal option. I simply do not see that a person in that situation must have the standards of others imposed upon them.
Of all the material that has crossed my desk there are two brief extracts that sum up where my thinking is. One is from Peter Baume who says:

Let us agree that the question is one of how we are to die. Palliative care should be available for all who need it. Its practitioners are doing more clever things and will continue to improve what they are doing year by year. But even the best palliative care will not solve all of the problems.

Let us regulate and control voluntary euthanasia rather than leaving it illegal and uncontrolled as it is now. It is at present an activity totally unregulated. One disturbing effect of present arrangements is that the powerful and the wealthy are more able to get access today than are the powerless and the poor. But finally, and most importantly, let us recognise the rights of people to make victimless decisions about themselves, for themselves, and then let us ensure that only those considered views are acted upon.
Another view that has certainly coloured my thinking is from Tony Staley, the President of the Liberal Party, a man who suffered appalling bodily damage in a car accident and who has said:
I do believe it needs to be carefully constrained by proper procedure to ensure that those who express the desire are absolutely firm in purpose. But for people in that situation—
and he is talking about those who really have no other option—
it is the last and great human right for them.

One of my branch members, a constituent, wrote to me recently to say that they were appalled by the fact that the Liberal Party, and members of the party, should be going down the route of trying to stop euthanasia. My constituent said:

. . . it beggars understanding that a Party which espouses as its core philosophy the right of the individual should run around in circles finding the most specious of arguments to deny the ultimate right to the individual, especially those who find themselves in circumstances beyond their control and without hope.

I have no doubt the cumulative MP conscience is being balmed by the view that it is not necessary for them to take a stand because euthanasia is already happening and no one is really suffering. It is so that it happens—it is not so that there is no suffering. Levels of pain or ability to cope with it is known only to the individual and cannot be generalised or understood by anyone else.

After much agonising and, I have to say, some doubt, it is my personal decision to support the pro‐choice view. Therefore, I will vote against the bill introduced by the member for Menzies because, ultimately, I believe people should have the right to choose to die with dignity if they wish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Entsch, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say from the beginning that, prior to the recent raising of the issue of the Northern Territory euthanasia legislation in this House, on a scale of critical issues, as I saw it, moral issues such as euthanasia rated pretty low in my priorities. It is not that I am insensitive or uncaring, but I have never really had to deal with the issue on a personal level and I therefore had no really strong feelings one way or the other. As you may be well aware, I am very much a new member of this House. I guess you could call me a member of the Class of `96. I am not only a new member but I also admit that I am very new to politics. If you had asked me two years ago if I would be interested in a career in politics, I can assure you the response would have been a firm `no'.

SPEECH.PARA: What changed my point of view was, in all honesty, nothing to do with how the government of the day was dealing with moral issues, but what I saw as its dismal performance on issues such as economics, unemployment and industrial relations, and its failure to address the needs of families, the elderly, our youth and small business. I was also very angry at the way our grassroots Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people were being treated, the abuse of the people of Cape York generally, and the inequities and divisiveness of our current native title legislation.

Those were the reasons I decided to walk away from a very successful career in private enterprise and take the advice of a dear old friend who had said one evening, after a very unsuccessful and frustrating meeting with the then local federal member in the Cape York town of Coen, `If you want a change of attitude, change the government.' This was after I had expressed my total despair at where I thought we, as a nation, were heading. Well, here I am. We have had a change of government and, undoubtedly, a change of attitude. I am very much prepared to fight for the changes that I feel we need to improve the quality of life and security for all Australians.

At this point I am not prepared to go down the track of attempting to right all the perceived moral issues of this nation. Like the previous speaker, the member for Aston (Mr Nugent), I have been absolutely bombarded with letters, with individual representations and by lobby groups from both extremes of the argument. Most of them, I have to say, have come from outside my electorate. There is a pro‐euthanasia organisation in my electorate and also a right to life organisation. But most of the lobbying has come from outside the electorate.

I also have to say that I have seen some dreadfully sad examples of how people have been desperately wanting or needing to depart this world and they have given me some very strong arguments as to why they should. Equally, I have had arguments from people who have come up with examples of where people could have taken an easy option—and possibly would have taken it if it had been available to them—but at the end of the day there had been quite pleasant and miraculous results. It was very difficult to say that one side had come up with stronger arguments than the other—I think both of them were very strong. So, at the end of all of this, I am certainly more informed on the subject, but, in spite of intense lobbying, I want to remain focused on why I intended to come into this House in the first instance.

Looking quickly at the Northern Territory euthanasia law, I say to you that I have some concerns with regard to it. As an individual, I do not know whether I would be prepared to avail myself of it. If it were an option that I had to consider in my own state of Queensland, I would have very serious reservations about supporting that legislation. If it were a national issue, again I would have to look at it on its merits at the time and I would have very serious reservations.

There are arguments here that the word `territory' means that it is not a state. I suppose that technically that is correct. But I think the reality is that we have a government democratically elected by the majority of the Northern Territory people. As I understand it, when the decision was made to put this bill through in the Northern Territory they voted on it not once but twice, and it clearly reflected the view of the majority of the people in the Northern Territory.

Something I hold very dear that is very important and that we, as politicians or legislators, must always remember is that we are here in this House as representatives of the people and it is our responsibility to reflect the views of the people—we are to enact legislation that reflects the needs and the aspirations of the people. We have state and territory governments that are separate from our national houses. The Northern Territory people have spoken quite clearly on this; they have made a decision that this is what they want, and their government has legislated to fulfil that requirement.

BREAK.PARA: I believe that if there is a major problem with that legislation, then the Northern Territory people have the avenues available to them to stop it at the next election. They can vote their government out as quickly as they voted it in if they make that decision and that is the route they wish to take—that is something that they have to choose to do. As a national government, if we start interfering with the decisions that are made by democratically elected state or territory governments, we run the real risk at the end of the day of having to ask: where do we go to next? The ACT has legislation on marijuana laws and a whole range of other things that are totally unacceptable in my state. Do we come in here and tell the ACT that we are going to override that legislation? Are we going to start dealing next year with capital punishment in legislation? In the meantime, we start to go down the gurgler from an economic point of view. I think that we have a responsibility to the whole range of issues that we were put into government to deal with and I continue to focus on those. As a government, we need to make sure that we maintain those priorities.

The big problem in the Northern Territory was not that we suddenly had a group of Australians that were mad keen on killing off their elderly, sick or infirm; quite the contrary. I think we may well have had a situation where palliative care was not seen as a high priority and, as a consequence, there were a lot of people who were suffering unnecessarily. I think that we, as a government, need to look at addressing that. It is all very well to provide the best of palliative care in the urban areas of Australia, but we must not forget that there are also very large populations living in rural and remote areas of Australia who suffer equally and I feel we need to start to focus on these areas. I think this will very much be a deterrent for people wanting to take this option of voluntary euthanasia.

I will be focusing my interests on the palliative care side of things, in the hope that we can discourage anybody else from enacting this type of legislation. The decision that is being made in the Northern Territory is on the conscience of the citizens of the Northern Territory and if they, in any way, feel that it is not working or it is inappropriate, they certainly have the ability to change the legislation or to replace their government with one with a different point of view. (Time expired)

Mr BILLSON (Dunkley) (12.07 p.m.) Firstly, I acknowledge the presence of my parliamentary colleagues, particularly the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) for being fulsome and energetic in his provision of information. I thank him for that. I am of a mind to support the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. There is a certain irony to matters of conscience in this place. Someone else determines when your conscience is to be on exhibition. This has not been an easy matter for me. I have not retreated from the debate, nor sought the easy comfort of viewing this matter simply as a single dimension states rights issue, or a moral conviction or personal liberty question. For me it is a complex mix of all of these considerations and many more, no doubt coloured by my own personal experiences.

It is naive for the proponents of the Northern Territory legislation to claim that the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act is a matter solely for territorians. The act has consequences far beyond the territory boundaries. The federal parliament has the power to enact overriding legislation, as the territory legislature is a creation of the Commonwealth's self‐government legislation. Notwithstanding this fact, I would have preferred standing here today to debate a proactive Commonwealth position rather than something that reacts to the actions of another legislature.

I genuinely believe that every member who has spoken on this bill speaks with a heart full of compassion. No side of this debate can claim, in my view, a greater care or concern for the well‐being of fellow Australians. Having apprised myself of available material, listened carefully to and sought opinion on this matter, my response to the more than 100 people who have written to me about this subject outlines my thinking.

One person, a friend and a significant contributor of time and energy to my election on 2 March, chose to respond to my written advice. While he agreed to disagree with my conclusion, my approach was accepted as thoughtful, considered and informed. It was the approach of a legislator. My inquiries and deliberations centred on three core questions. What is the public policy imperative of the Northern Territory law? What is the problem it is trying to solve for the betterment of the community? Is the response likely to achieve these goals?

My qualified general support for the Andrews bill comes out of the fact that the Northern Territory act seeks to solve a problem that does not exist. More precisely, I believe that, in seeking to solve a non‐existent problem, the Northern Territory legislation actually creates new real problems that are of far greater concern than the issues that the Northern Territory legislature sought to address in the first place.

At common law, a competent adult can refuse medical treatment, and treatment of a patient against the wishes of the patient constitutes the tort of trespass. In my home state of Victoria, and also in South Australia, laws permit passive voluntary euthanasia where parents can deny or instruct the withdrawal of medical treatment, and death results. Not one Australian medical practitioner has been prosecuted for administering a palliative care or pain management regime—to deal with patient pain and suffering—which hastens death.

I put my public policy questions, framed in the light of reported accounts of what the current reality is, to the Northern Territory act's proponent. He responded that the public policy imperative was solely equity, in the belief that worse‐off people are denied the choices and support which better‐off people have access to. Having thought about this perspective, I rejected it. All the advice, experiences, choices and information which I have drawn from and have contemplated are available to every citizen of Dunkley.

The bulk‐billing doctors who are a part of the Mornington Peninsula division of general practice, our excellent local hospice service, palliative care experts, carers themselves and support service providers are all part of the safety net of support services of our community. The procedures contained in the Northern Territory legislation are likely to reduce the options available to the terminally ill patient for the management of their own suffering. The obligations on medical and psychological practitioners to publicly sign off on a competent individual's decision to end their own life is not welcomed by most practitioners, because of the professional implications. The link between terminal illness and depression is widely published.

Protecting the frail and vulnerable from coercive external influences is a matter not sufficiently addressed by the Northern Territory act. This matter, above all, was the subject of the most moving commentary in the letters I have received.
