Some frail, ill and elderly people confided in me that they already felt that they were a burden and a nuisance to loved ones. I am not convinced that you can legislate for compassion, care, sensitivity and safety on such personal issues, which each have their own circumstances and unique considerations. I believe that choices about the management of the suffering associated with terminal illness are essentially a private matter, with the role of government being the provision of appropriate and professional palliative care to support personal choice.

Individuals exercise their choices, guided by their own trusted medical practitioners and advisers, and before their own conscience, their own family and their own God, if they have one, and as they believe appropriate. This was the case before the Northern Territory legislation and, hopefully, will again be the situation if the Andrews bill passes through both houses of parliament. While I stop short of commending the bill to other members of this House, because of the reservations I have mentioned earlier, it is my intention to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that, of recent times, it is in order to change one's mind on the position one takes in regard to the matter of terminating one's life. I must say that I find this debate on the Euthanasia Laws Bill unhappy and unnecessary but, nevertheless, extremely difficult, as has been the comment of many people in the process of past weeks. In making a decision as to which way I came down, as a famous duke once said, I found it a `near‐run thing'. Nevertheless, I can make that decision.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many aspects which have been covered by other members in this chamber, and I would like to make a few points. On almost every one of these points, my decision one way or another has been at the margin. In the end, I do not believe that, where there is chronic and insufferable physical or mental pain or where a person knows they are losing their mental capabilities (as is the case in various forms of dementia, and I have had reason in recent weeks to see somebody quite close to my family be in the situation of writing himself notes every day to remind himself of his name) people should not be allowed to show some sort of control over what would perhaps be their final act, before either passing into insensibility, perhaps for months or years, or otherwise living in circumstances of extreme or even unbearable pain.

I understand the situation about palliative care, and I understand that there is absolutely no doubt that some medical practitioners know for a fact that, if administered for long enough and at high enough levels, certain practices will finish in death; and I have no problem whatsoever with that. But, in the rare case—and I think it really is a rare case—that some people want to end their lives, then, on the margin, they should not be prevented from doing so.

I say that in the light of the many conditions that were put in place under the Northern Territory bill. How many times have we heard of, or known of, people who, having had a marvellous life, perhaps in extreme old age—and more people are living to extreme old age these days than did before—are now totally immobile and in deteriorating physical or mental circumstances, and who say that they wish that they could go to sleep and not wake up in the morning? But some of us are going to say, `All of those circumstances could be there; but I, from my position, am going to say to you that you do not have that choice available to you.' In general, we are saying today that, in a relatively free society, all through your life the one thing we want to give you, wherever we possibly can, is choice. Yet this final choice is going to be denied, perhaps because of people's religious beliefs. Perhaps because of my religious belief, am I to say, `I am telling you that you are not allowed by law to have a dignified exit'?

In the short time we have in this debate, I would say that the essence of the argument in favour of being able to terminate your own life is really a matter of choice in extreme circumstances. The argument against euthanasia seems to form around two particular matters: one with a basis in religion, and the second in concern about potential abuses; and I notice that Holland seems to be much quoted. I am not aware of abuses in Holland, but it seems to me that the Northern Territory bill itself has at least 22 checkpoints.

The chart—which, I understand, was attributed to the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas), but which somebody else, in fact, drew up—is really like a Monopoly board. There is a series of Monopoly‐like gates that you have to pass through, and more conditions as well. I am not talking about Holland; I am talking about the Northern Territory bill. It seems nigh on impossible that anyone who did not want to terminate their life could possibly pass through all those checkpoints and actually get to the point where the button was pressed—which is, as I said, what the Northern Territory bill is about; and the present bill is about terminating the Northern Territory bill. If we agree—but we obviously do not—that the Northern Territory bill is faulty, it can only be faulty in very minor ways, and it seems to me almost impossible that many people could pass through those gates successfully if, in fact, they did not want to terminate their life.

The debate, then, comes down to whether others should prevent me or anybody terminating my or his life in regard to those 22 particular conditions. Like everybody else, I have had plenty of letters in recent days. I have had an orchestrated campaign, I have to say, over the last six or seven weeks. Up until that point, the letters were running about fifty‐fifty—I think they were probably slightly in favour of terminating one's own life—but since then they have run the other way. I have checked my records and, prior to the introduction of this bill we are debating today, I may have had one letter ever on the subject. With 82,000 people in my electorate, I had only had one letter on the subject of termination of life—even after the Northern Territory legislation was in place.

I have come to the conclusion that what was happening was that people who were interested were watching what was going on in the Northern Territory. In other words, here was a small jurisdiction, they had passed a bill—call it a bill about euthanasia or a bill about the right to terminate life of the terminally ill who made that choice themselves—and we were sitting there, and I think they were sitting there, saying, `There is an interesting thing taking place up there in the Territory, there is a limited number of people, it is limited jurisdiction and we will watch and see what happens.' They were watching to see, as with many of the fears expressed in this debate, whether or not the right to terminate life was going to escape out of the Northern Territory bottle. What has happened is that what is proposed in this bill is that nobody is going to be able to see whether or not it would have escaped out of the Northern Territory bottle, because the bill proposes that the lid goes on the bottle and the bottle is thrown out to sea. So I have to say that, for a number of reasons, I will oppose this bill.

My last reason is that I think, in the main, whilst I agree absolutely that this Commonwealth parliament has the right to dispose of or terminate legislation brought down in the Northern Territory, that it is not a matter of whether it has the right; it is a matter of whether it should or should not in this case. I cannot see the point of creating territories which have their own legislatures, allowing them to legislate and then, sometime later, making a decision that you are going to terminate some piece of legislation they have brought down. If they are responsible enough to legislate on the matter, then we should allow that legislation to carry through. So, to repeat what I have said, it is a near run thing but, on the margin, I have to say that I have come down in favour of allowing the Northern Territory legislation to stand. I will therefore vote against this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —So far into this debate, little new can be said that has not already been put more eloquently by those who have spoken before me. But I want to at least explain to my constituency how I have come to my position on the Euthanasia Laws Bill and what issues I have taken into account in reaching my conclusions. In my view, there are three basic issues to decide in determining how I should vote on the Andrews bill. The first question is: is this bill a proper exercise of Commonwealth powers? The second is: does the bill enjoy community support? The third is: should euthanasia be permitted in Australia?

SPEECH.PARA: I know that for many of those who have spoken in this debate the first two issues are not considered to be of great consequence. I have been somewhat disappointed that some members seek to discount the significance of those two questions and want to deal exclusively with the morality of euthanasia itself. However, it is my view that ours is a constitutional democracy with a defined balance of powers between the Commonwealth, states and territories, and that we have a representative parliamentary system whose members have an obligation to represent the views of their constituencies. I want to be satisfied in relation to all three of these matters before casting my vote on the Andrews bill.

I have no doubt that the constitutional responsibility to make laws in relation to euthanasia rests with the states. It is not a matter of state rights. Indeed, I reject the concept of state or Commonwealth or territory rights. It is the people who have rights; governments have responsibilities. But the federation would be clearly unworkable if one tier of government ever sought to illegitimately extend its powers at the expense of others. There has been, over recent times, a graphic shift of responsibility as the Commonwealth has used the external affairs powers, its superior financial powers and, indeed, an expansive High Court to extend its influence at the expense of the states.

I have taken a stand on this issue in the past. In October 1994, I voted against the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill. I did so because I believed that legislation overrode lawfully made decisions of the Tasmanian government, and decisions for which the Tasmanian government had received a recent mandate from its people. I had no doubt that the state had the power to make the laws that it made in that regard and that it had exercised those powers correctly. The Commonwealth intervention was based on a misrepresentation of an international treaty. It was supported by very dubious High Court rulings. It was also based on hopelessly flawed United Nations Human Rights Committee rulings, where the hearings were conducted without any natural justice. Those decisions, and that Commonwealth act changed, in my view, the balance intended under our constitution. It sought to enable the Commonwealth to intervene in areas where it had no reasonable right to intervene.

However, this euthanasia case is somewhat different. There is no United Nations treaty, no human rights committee, no endorsement of flawed procedures, and no attempt to override the intended balance of powers between the Commonwealth and the states. Indeed, there is no doubt that, when the founding fathers met to draw up our constitution, they clearly intended that the territories would be regarded differently from the states in the way in which powers were distributed between the various tiers of government.

Section 122 of the constitution quite clearly says that the `parliament may make laws for the government of any territory'. It does not say that about the states but it does make a very clear distinction in relation to the territories. Clearly, the Northern Territory is not a state. It has ambitions to be a state, ambitions which I support, but it is not yet a state. It is not, in my view, accidental that the founding fathers included this particular section in our constitution. I believe they took that action because of the small numbers of people living in the territories. It was always intended that, as a territory grew, it would become a state and enjoy the same rights and responsibilities and privileges of the other states.

If we look at this particular decision, and, indeed, many others, we can see that the territories could in fact make decisions within their own parliaments, their own assemblies, which affect all Australians. This is one such example. It is incomprehensible to believe that the decision of the Northern Territory will not affect all Australians. If this legislation stays, an industry to provide euthanasia will quickly develop in the Northern Territory. A state that has no palliative care industry would instead have an industry that facilitates death.

Therefore, this small section of the Australian population—less than one per cent—would effectively be deciding the euthanasia issue for all. It was decided in the Northern Territory assembly, a single house without any review, with the smallest possible majority. Indeed, it was a majority which disappeared on the substantive issue at the next by-election. In my view, it is perfectly reasonable for the Commonwealth to exercise powers, clearly given to it in section 122 of the constitution, to make a decision about whether the Northern Territory legislation is appropriate.

Whether the Andrews bill enjoys majority public support is not clear. Public opinion polls seem to support euthanasia, but there is real doubt that the public understands that this bill—and, indeed, the Northern Territory legislation—is not about withdrawing pointless medical treatment which prolongs a painful end. It is about active intervention to kill, even if in prescribed circumstances. The correspondence in my electorate overwhelmingly supports the Andrews bill. But most of it comes from organised lobby groups, so it cannot be regarded as being definitively reflective of the views of my electorate and I must make the decision as I see the issues.

To me, euthanasia is not just another medical procedure; it is the ultimate, final act. It is not just an issue for those who are choosing to die; it affects also their families and friends. The impact on a family of the first legal euthanasia is so apparent on this day. Too often, parents feel that they have become a burden on their family. They have in many instances worked hard and gone without, all of their lives, to save up an inheritance for their family, being themselves prepared to do without to give their children a better chance in life. I fear that this moral pressure which parents so often feel may lead them to say, `Let me also ease the burden on my children in these last days and make a voluntary decision to terminate my life.'

`Euthanasia', I am told, is a Greek work meaning easy death. But there is no easy death. Coming to terms with dying is a very important part of living. Leaving this world content, being at peace with God and fellow man is, I think, important to most Australians, and to most people when they are facing their last times. Who knows what benefit someone, even someone who is terminally ill, may still provide to those around—a strengthening word, an example of courage, an expression of faith that helps someone else.

As I have been listening to the very powerful and moving stories of so many members of parliament who have referred in this debate to their own experiences of being close to someone who has died, I have wondered how many of such people, in their latter years, thought about how important their death would be in a national debate on an important issue. Who knows what final contribution, even in our last hours, we may be able to make to help others and to assist our community.

BREAK.PARA: I have never personally been a supporter of euthanasia. I have not been persuaded during this debate that I should change my mind. So I have decided to support the Andrews bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieberman, Lou, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —When an elected member of parliament who belongs to a political party is able to vote on an issue, the community usually—and sometimes cynically—says, `Oh, well, the member follows the party line.' That is an oversimplification of the role of a member of parliament who belongs to a political party and is unfair, because policy decisions result from many people in that party working and contributing towards a resolution and a policy outcome. However, when a member belongs to a political party that says also that members may exercise a right to vote on an issue if it can fairly be categorised as a conscience issue, I think that member can proudly say that he belongs to a party which recognises the sensitivities of issues and allows members to vote according to conscience without any recrimination.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly pleased that, in the whole of this parliament, members from all parties have been given the privilege of voting according to their conscience on this important legislation, the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, even though some of those members not belonging to my party do not normally have that right. Parliament is enriched by the process.

Secondly, members of the community in my electorate have spoken to me and said, `Lou, you really should vote the way we say you should. After all, it is what we want you to do. It is our will.' I try to explain to those people, `Yes, I respect your view and I am interested to learn about it and to discuss it with you. But it is not the view of all of my electorate.' It is quite strange when they then say, `Oh, but it must be. How can anyone not have a view the same as ours?'

It is an interesting paradox that a member of parliament has to explain sometimes to his individual electors that what they say to him is not necessarily the same as the views of the rest of the constituents. Like other colleagues, I have had a lot of correspondence, phone calls, and personal conversations with people in my electorate about this issue. If I were wanting to count up the number of people that have actually taken the trouble to contact me, I would find that most would overwhelmingly be against euthanasia and would overwhelmingly want me to vote in support of the Andrews legislation and thus frustrate the Northern Territory parliament in its legislative program.

But I have been around a while and I am also aware of the fact that the silent majority often does not take the trouble to express its view. You cannot always say to yourself, as a parliamentarian, that since you have got most letters from people who take one view, it therefore follows ipso facto that that is the view of the whole electorate. I do not take that view. My own conscience view is—and always has been, and I believe always will be—that life is precious, and that the mysteries of life are not always understood, and I certainly do not understand them fully. I personally would always strongly oppose euthanasia.

As a former minister for health and a shadow minister for health in the Victorian parliament, I was often confronted with the dilemma of trying to find enough resources to meet all of the health needs of the community. There are cogent arguments put to you to fund this and not, perhaps, put as much into another area. That is one of the dilemmas, of course, of being in public life and making decisions that often you have to balance things.

I do not see any compromise on the question of legalising euthanasia. It is something that I cannot support. I remember when I was at the Royal Women's Hospital in Melbourne and being shown the premature babies in that particular area where with great skill many babies have been saved and have gone on to become healthy children and adults and productive citizens of this country. I can remember one of the bureaucrats saying, `Minister, you know it costs, I think, $27,000 a week to keep these babies alive. You know, Minister, you are going to have to—' I said, `No, I don't know.' `You know, Minister?' I said, `No, I don't know.' But I knew he meant, of course, that maybe the funds should be cut off. There was no way that I would adhere to that, either.

I have been a strong advocate of the development in Australia of palliative care. I think that is an issue. I have asked a lot of people who have been opposed to us opposing this euthanasia law whether they understood that in Victoria, in particular, and in other states, there is the right to refuse medical treatment. I played a little role in that when I was in the Victorian parliament in helping to develop those laws. They are surprised—and many citizens of Australia do not understand—that there are now legislative rights in most states to refuse medical treatment which prolongs that person's life when that person does not want support systems. There is now a right to refuse. When I explained that, I found a lot of people who were wanting to have euthanasia laws said, `That is all I need, Lou. I am happy with that and I do not particularly want to go ahead with supporting euthanasia.'

Coming from a state parliament and now in the federal parliament, I respect very much the sovereignty and the principle of the elected parliament being accountable and having its rights to enact laws, even though you may not approve of them, without interference from central government. So you can understand that I am in some quandary here, except that I believe that under section 122 of the constitution, federal parliamentarians are expected to maintain their duties and responsibilities and not abrogate them. So I do not find the arguments against interference with the Northern Territory parliament very strong at all.

The other point is that the Northern Territory law has extra‐jurisdictional operation. In fact, people have already moved from my home town in Victoria to the Northern Territory to seek access to the Northern Territory law. So it is a nonsense to say that the Northern Territory law only applies to Northern Territorians. It has the potential to apply to all Australians. That is another reason why the Commonwealth parliament has a legitimate right, in my view, to debate the issue.

Secondly, in the abstract, it can also be argued that the Commonwealth commitment to health funding through Medicare and other grant systems involves interconnection between the Commonwealth and the states and territories. So Commonwealth parliamentarians have the responsibility anyway in the knowledge that, if one territory in Australia has a law like this, it is going to act as a magnet for people from other parts of Australia. They will want to avail themselves of this law.

I go back to the fact that our responsibility is to work as hard as we can to improve access to and the quality and effectiveness of palliative care. That is the important area. I am not here to moralise about the painful process of death. Obviously, I have had family and friends involved in that process, as we all have. However, from all the reading I have done and instruction that I have received, I strongly believe that palliative care can give relief to people who are suffering, and it can give it in a way which is dignified and which assists them to cope with a difficult passage of time. However, I know that more needs to be done in that area.

I pay tribute to the people in my electorate who are committed to developing those programs, particularly for rural people on farms and in isolation who do not have access to palliative care as you and I who live in large communities have. I pay tribute to those people in my electorate who are pioneering the development in Australia of palliative care to isolated communities and to people on farms through volunteers and visits and the like. I just wanted to take the opportunity to mention those people and commend their work in this society.

Finally, I respect the right of people to disagree with me. I have no disrespect for their view. It is good for us to be able to participate in a debate on an issue as sensitive as this with goodwill and understanding on both sides. I have a final prayer for all the people of this world that this country and this nation will lead the world in caring for people in the right way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barresi, Phil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on the Euthanasia Laws Bill. I do so after careful consideration of the arguments put forward by both sides of the debate and after considerable consultation with my electorate. That consultation presented a number of highly emotive responses to the issue. It is easy to dismiss the arguments for euthanasia purely on religious grounds, or even to accept the case for euthanasia purely on civil libertarian grounds.

SPEECH.PARA: If that were the case I, like many Australians who have been raised in an essentially highly democratic, Christian dominated society, would experience little agony over the eventual decision. But that is not the case. To simply fall back on either of these values would be a betrayal of the trust that the voters of Deakin have placed in me.

There has been no shortage of interest groups—churches, community organisations, constituents and even party members—prepared to offer their counsel, opinion or, in some cases, their direction. I have also listened to the emotional and heartfelt personal accounts of those who have witnessed the slow demise of a loved one. I sincerely thank them all for their input and trust that they will understand, if not accept, my eventual, very personal vote on this matter.

I place on record my belief that the bill should have been referred to a House of Representatives parliamentary committee prior to being debated in this House. I know the arguments put forward by those who voted against this idea last month; arguments such as, `We need to get the matter over and done with as soon as possible', or `The longer we take, the greater the chance that Bob Dent will not be the only one to die as a result of the Northern Territory legislation', or `The Senate will refer the bill to a committee anyway'.
None of these arguments is convincing. A responsible parliament, as evidenced elsewhere in the world, has to conduct thorough research prior to considering such important and vital social issues.

To me it is not enough that the Northern Territory parliament has investigated the issue. We are not the Northern Territory parliament, we are not the House of Lords or the Canadian parliament all of which undertook comprehensive research. We are the Australian parliament and to abdicate that responsibility to a Senate committee or rely on another parliament's research is just not good enough. It is an abdication of our responsibility.

Let me also make it clear that my decision to vote for referral to a committee was in no way motivated by a desire to `park the bill'. This is too important a bill to ignore or to shunt off indefinitely into the too hard basket. For example, there are many unanswered questions in relation to the Northern Territory law. Even as recently as the day before the debate began I received legal opinion within my electorate concerned about the safeguards in respect to psychiatric cases.

BREAK.PARA: Against this backdrop, at the end of the day I am voting in support of this bill on a range of social, medical and moral grounds, some of which I would like to place on record today.

Like many other speakers, I fail to see the imperative to adopt euthanasia laws. Have our society, our medicos, our policy makers, been screaming out for action? Has there been a flaw in the system which needs to be fixed? Has palliative care been discredited? Unlike unemployment, business growth, education of our kids, investment in the future and the support of our traditional family structure, there is no imperative for euthanasia.

We are here today because of one man's personal crusade and because one territory took it upon itself to pass a law which affects all Australians, not just territorians or those currently with terminal illness, but all Australians. It is not confined to within the territory's borders.

Today, in 1996, it is easy to be swayed towards allowing euthanasia when we are confronted by the heartfelt and emotional stories depicting the slow deterioration of an individual's life. It is relatively easy to be swayed by the notion that we are being compassionate by removing the agony, the pain and the indignity of an individual's suffering. It is also easy to be swayed by misleading public opinion polls which ask, `Do you believe in relieving the suffering of a dying person?' Of course the answer would be yes, but does that response extend to, `Do you believe in terminating the individual's life?' I ask those that form their opinion and take solace from opinion polls or talkback radio to analyse the facts as I have had the opportunity to do. Interestingly, most people who engage on a path of research into this topic, as has been evidenced by former pro‐euthanasia proponents, have a realisation that the case for euthanasia is not so clear cut. Those pro‐euthanasia arguments must be considered in terms of the long‐term effect on our society.

In 2006, after 10 years, or even in 15 years after socialisation of normative behaviour by our institutions, politicians, doctors, or even families, what kind of a society will we have? I do not know the answer to that question, and while there are many unknowns about our future, can I, as a legislator, take a risk with the life of future generations? Can I, as a legislator who may, by that time, be retired, be assured of its administration?

In saying this I am mindful of four very important considerations. Firstly, can the safeguards and tests which will protect the voluntary aspect of euthanasia—the voluntary aspect of it which is often lauded by proponents of euthanasia—still be maintained? As a psychologist there is one thing that I know: the greatest predictor of future behaviour or performance can often be past performance. While that is not a truism, it is the best that we have got at this moment. Past performance and past experience, and even current behaviour in countries which sanction euthanasia, indicate that the answer to that is no.

The second consideration is that the role and the duty of a doctor will not be compromised. The integrity of the trust which currently exists between doctor and patient cannot be safeguarded. How do I calm the levels of anxiety which are bound to creep into an aged and invalid resident or patient as they are wheeled into a hospital or nursing home? These should be places where a high level of trust and faith in a positive outcome of support is evidenced, rather than places of suspicion and mistrust.

Thirdly, can we be assured that the growing army of palliative care volunteers will not lose heart? Volunteers in my electorate who belong to such organisations as the Nunawading Palliative Care Association and the Mid Eastern Palliative Care Association are people I respect and admire deeply. They are surrounded by those very people whom we are placing at risk by a future society where euthanasia has been normalised.

Finally, can I have faith that future legislators who are confronted by high current account deficits, high public spending, high inflation or growing unemployment will not rule a red line through research programs, tax initiatives, institutions, health programs and medical schools which are aimed either at finding remedies to current and unknown diseases or at relieving the suffering of those who are terminally ill? I say that because I have had the personal experience of knowing someone who died of a terminal illness only four or five years ago and whose life could perhaps have been prolonged today because of the continuing, extensive research into the disease.

I do not say these things lightly, but as a comment that we as a society are pressured to compete in an ever increasing and dependent global village. I also express these concerns based on the sense of urgency we experience when we are occasionally confronted by a mysterious disease. Would the world's medical research teams be mobilised to find a response to the growing list of cancers and to diseases such as AIDS? I am not convinced. I am not willing to take that chance for the sake of not today's Bob Dent, but tomorrow's infirm, diseased or incapacitated.

Finally, Mr Deputy Speaker, allow me to make a closing statement to the people of the Northern Territory and to my friend, Shane Stone, the Chief Minister. I do not believe that the rights and status of the Northern Territory are diminished in the eyes of the public or in the eyes of many of our federal parliamentarians. This issue must be considered by the federal parliament. It is too important an issue for us to hide behind the states rights argument. After careful consideration, I give my support to the private member's bill as proposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter, Bob, Jnr, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In Charters Towers, my home town for the second half of my life, we had a case that got great national prominence when a young lady was accused of the mass murder of six people who were terminally ill. The case that touched this off was a hard case, and I think the territory people advocating euthanasia would use the Bucholz case as the sort that euthanasia would address. The case got enormous publicity—it was on 60 Minutes and on at least two occasions it was on the front of every newspaper in Australia. The original case that touched it off concerned a person who was in a very advanced stage of cancer. If he had not been under a drugs regime he would have been enduring enormous pain and his body was in a very advanced state of deterioration. That was the background to the case concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Since all of the players involved were very well known to me I did a little bit of research. I went over and spoke to the top person in the field of drugs and drug administration in Townsville and asked if I could discuss the case with her. I asked, `What happens in a case like this? Here is a person in a very advanced state of deterioration and who is most certainly terminally ill. If you take away the drugs regime that person will be in incredible pain. Since we can never actually prise our way into people's consciousness, maybe he is in incredible pain now, we do not know. We cannot say definitively'.

The person concerned said that in the real world where real people live, as opposed to where the politically correct brigade live, if a person is dying there are three states that they will be in. In the first state they will be in great pain in which case they will be getting a very high regime of morphine. In the second state they will be dying but be in no pain, in which case it would be impossible to justify euthanasia. The third state is dementia and that is a grey area that the lady did not wish to go into.

BREAK.PARA: I said, `Come back to the morphine'. She said, `Morphine is a poison. The higher the regime, the shorter your lifespan'. So the more intense the administration of morphine, the shorter will be the lifespan. She said, `In the real world that is the reason why euthanasia is not a big issue. In the world where we live, in hospitals, that is not a big issue'. Whilst the AMA has taken some dreadful decisions which clearly indicate that they have a fairly cavalier attitude towards medical health in Australia, on this issue they have stood their ground on a matter of principle. Doctors know that in the real world there is a way of dealing with this. That is the way that it is dealt with and that is the way that it has been dealt with over a very long period of time.

Dealing with the case where there is great pain, the solution employed is the morphine solution. I do not like using that description because it was the same term used by the Germans to do away with anyone who had dementia or who was a little bit less than perfect or who was a burden upon the state, and I think that that is very relevant to the debate here today. But in the first case, that case is dealt with in a manner which everyone has found reasonably acceptable over a very long period of time.
In the second case, if there is no pain then there is no desire for euthanasia. It would be a very rare occurrence. There is no great issue involved there.

The third case which concerns me greatly is the dementia case. In Charters Towers we have the mental hospital which serves the northern half of Queensland. We also have the Eventide Hospital for old people who are in an advanced state of physical disability. One runs across an awful lot of people in this particular grey area. I remember one particular case where there was the most violent fight going on between the hospital employees union and a doctor at the Eventide Hospital over a gentlemen who had a gangrenous leg. The doctor was arguing that the leg could not be taken off because the person had said that it could not be taken off whereas the nurses, the attendants at the Eventide Hospital, said that unless the leg was taken off then clearly the man would die. That was the reason for the violent altercation.

I went and saw the man myself and I said, `Mate, your leg has got gangrene and unless it's taken off you are going to die. Could we please take your leg off?' He then said yes. So I walked down the corridor and had a cup of tea and then came back and said to him, `The hospital doctor is saying you shouldn't have your leg taken off because you don't want to have your leg taken off. Is it true that you don't want to have your leg taken off?' He said, `Yes, it is true that I don't want to have my leg taken off'.

It was quite obvious that anyone could walk in and elicit any sort of an answer from this gentlemen. However, I would not have described the man as a dementia case. He was a person you could talk to, although he was a little incoherent at times. He was most certainly not a case for euthanasia. Clearly, I could have elicited an answer from him saying, `Yes, I agree to be done away with'.

Therefore, the euthanasia area is an extremely dangerous one with respect to dementia. It is an extremely dangerous mechanism to put into the hands of a lot of doctors. They have studied hard all of their lives, and I think that the human element of their personality has been destroyed by the intense study regime which they have committed themselves to over a long period of time. I would see them as remarkably inappropriate people to have such an extremely dangerous mechanism as this. Also, in the case of dementia, people go in and out of it. You can have periods where they are extremely lucid and it would be terrible to conceive of any of my friends or relatives being done away with because they were going through a period of dementia when they might otherwise have come out of it later on. That would be terrible.

There are two other possibilities that must be canvassed here, in my opinion. We are all human and we have very great financial burdens to carry, particularly in a country where over a million families have gone broke and lost everything over the last decade. But, probably, it is true at all times that people are under financial pressure. You may have a person whose grown‐up children are under terrific financial pressure. They are about to have their home taken away from them, or their kids have to be pulled out of school because there is not enough money to keep them at school or university. And there is an old person that has a home and some assets. There is enormous pressure, both upon the children to recommend that daddy be speeded on his way and, sadly, there is tremendous pressure upon daddy himself. The more he stays alive, the less access the kids have got to his life insurance and, to a lesser extent, his assets and property.

So, he has a terrible decision to make: whether to stay alive and watch his children go bankrupt, be taken out of university and thrown on the economic scrap heap; or to take his own life. That is the only way that his children would be entitled to his life insurance, and with life insurance and superannuation, most people have very substantial sums of money tied up.

Also, a person still has some tenuous clinging to hope, no matter how hopeless his position is and, as the member for Deakin (Mr Barresi) pointed out, who knows what miracles medical science will come up with in a period of three or four years. The year before Dr Barnard did his famous heart transplant who would have remotely conceived that you could take a person's heart out and put somebody else's heart in that person and he would live on. The wonders of medical science are occurring every day and so people cling to hope. That clinging to hope would lead them not to sell off their homes. It places people in the twilight of their lives in a dreadful situation because now they will go out being very displeased with their children, or the children will be very displeased with themselves. (Time expired)

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.04 p.m. until 4.32 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mrs DE‐ANNE KELLY

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, also known as the Andrews bill. Firstly, I would like to go to the question of whether we should be debating this matter in the federal parliament. While I am a supporter of state rights, I believe that there are two compelling reasons why it is appropriate that this debate occur in the federal parliament. Firstly, under the constitution, the Commonwealth has a right to do so. Section 122 of the constitution states that:

SPEECH.PARA: The parliament may make laws for the government of any territory. . .
Mr Andrews's bill will amend the Northern Territory (Self Government) Act to insert the provision 6A(1) which states that:
The Legislative Assembly does not have power to make a law to permit assistance to be given to a person to terminate his or her life.

The second reason is a moral and legislative responsibility. This is not a new law for only the Northern Territory, or a new law only for Australia. It is, with only a few exceptions, a new law across all nations. The consequences of the Northern Territory law cannot be bound by the boundaries of that state. It will seep like a dye thrown into a pond and it will stain the lives and colour the thinking of all Australians.

Firstly, I would like to define what euthanasia is not. The turning off of a machine, or the withdrawal of treatment which has become a burden, or is futile or unwanted, is not euthanasia provided the intention is not to kill the patient. Providing sufficient pain relief to a patient is not euthanasia, even if that treatment also hastens death. Euthanasia is the deliberate intention to kill another human being. Euthanasia is not a right to die; it is a right to kill.

If the patient has requested that he or she be killed, it is termed voluntary euthanasia. If he or she is unable to make a conscious decision to request to be killed, but a relative or guardian requests it in the belief that this is what the patient would have wanted, it is called non‐voluntary euthanasia. Most of those who are pro‐euthanasia, as I found in my electorate, have very worthy reasons to support their view. They had a relative or friend who suffered greatly from a terminal illness and, quite rightly, they are concerned that such suffering should not continue for others—a very worthy aim. However, if we allow those in authority to take euthanasia as the easy way out, we will never see the good palliative care in this country that we must have.

The treatment and care of the dying is a specialist field and one still lacking in many hospitals in Australia. In the past, and even today, many people die with a great deal of suffering. The answer to this suffering is not to kill them or to euthanase them, but to offer them the very best palliative care.

I would like to quote Dr Brian Pollard who, after 30 years as an anaesthetist, commenced service at Concord Hospital in 1982 to care for the dying. He has cared for over 1,000 patients and could be expected to have a clear understanding of the facts and falsehoods associated with dying. He said:

Of all the causes of suffering, pain is the most prominent and the most feared. The methods for the control of pain in terminal illness are different from those needed for other illnesses and failure to appreciate this distinction is possibly the commonest reason why such pain is often not as well managed as it ought to be.
He went on to say:
There are few pains due to cancer which today cannot be either eliminated or reduced in intensity to the point where the patient can bear the residual amount.

To those who say that it is very easy for me to quote doctors, to quote learned professionals in the field, I would just say that I have personal knowledge. Eight years ago my father contracted a terminal illness and suffered a great deal over 18 months. I was with him when he died. Palliative care, even as little as eight years ago, was poor, although I believe sincerely that the doctors and nurses who cared for him did their very best.

I understand the sadness and the periods of anger and depression that dying people experience, and the frustration, confusion and hopelessness of the relatives. It would be very easy when a patient is depressed and in pain for the family who are feeling frustrated and burdened to come together and say, `The best way out is euthanasia.' However, I have seen the opportunity arise for very rich moments for families and for the dying: the opportunity to see a newborn grandchild, or the opportunity to say things that would have been left unsaid.

If lives are not sacred, no matter how diminished those lives may be in our opinion, then no life is sacrosanct. If we allow euthanasia to become acceptable, to receive the stamp of authority of our parliaments, then palliative care will never improve. I have a great fear—it is a bit like the shampoo commercial in that it won't happen overnight, but it will happen—that, in the future, what McDonald's has done for food, euthanasia will do for palliative care. We will have fast food and fast death.

The temptation for private health insurance, for instance, to differentiate between those who do the right thing and agree to save the health insurance industry a great deal of money and those who do not would be enormous. I fear for those who are vulnerable, who are dying. It is a time when one is very much at the mercy of others. I fear for those who are poor, for those who perhaps do not have the ability to argue their case. It would be so easy to be coerced.

Perhaps this is a little unfair, but I understand that the term amongst the pro‐euthanasia lobby for those who are contemplating or being given the option of euthanasia is `warm bodies'. If any phrase emphasises the dehumanisation of the individual, the term `warm bodies' is one that, frankly, I find very sad.

I do not want to introduce an element of levity into such a serious argument, but I can foresee a time when a son going to visit his mother who is ill in hospital would say to her, `Look Mum, Mrs Smith down the hall has done the right thing. You're really being difficult. Matron is upset by this. She wants someone else to have this bed—a young person. We are looking at selling the house and everything you have—but it is your decision, Mum. We could send the children to school, we could pay off our house with that money—but it is your decision, Mum.'

I can see, unfortunately, the commercialisation of euthanasia, with a loving package that you could have with your favourite movie, nightgown, and perhaps a day out. This is a time when those most vulnerable in our community should not be commercialised, should not have their humanity reduced. I support good palliative care, the sanctity of human life, and I support the Andrews bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McDougall, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Issues such as this tear at the very thread of Australia's soul. The euthanasia debate—

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 4.42 p.m. to 5.12 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said, issues such as this tear at the very thread of Australia's soul. The euthanasia debate has polarised our community as, no doubt, every member in this House can attest. Recently, in the space of three minutes, I took two independent calls from constituents. The first threatened, in no uncertain terms, never to vote for me or the Liberal Party again if I did not support the Andrews bill. The second, in no uncertain terms, said that neither she nor her aged mother would vote for me or the Liberal Party again if I did support the Andrews bill.

SPEECH.PARA: This pattern has been repeated in calls and letters to my office. It would appear that, to represent my constituents, I must vote both ways. In my years in business and as a city councillor, I cannot recall ever receiving so much information on one subject; certainly not from so many diverse groups, organisations, affiliated organisations and voters. But most are from outside my electorate and most are from outside Queensland. Everything that has been presented to me has been deserving of serious consideration and respect.
I know that the elected members of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly weighed up similar information and gave equally as serious—

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 5.13 p.m. to 5.48 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before the division, everything that has been presented to me has been deserving of serious consideration and respect. I know that the elected members of the Northern Territory assembly weighed up similar information and gave equally serious consideration to the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act when it was first passed in 1995. What concerns me is that this government chose not to take action at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth government had the right, under the Northern Territory (Self‐Government) Act 1978, to intervene if it felt it was necessary to do so. The Governor‐General had six months to recommend any amendments to the law or disallow the law, but the Governor‐General, on the advice of the Commonwealth government, assented to the legislation in June 1995.

The Commonwealth government had another chance to intervene in this matter when an amendment was presented in February this year. Once again, the Governor‐General did not disallow the amending legislation. I ask the obvious question: why? Why are we considering taking historically unprecedented action at this stage? I hate to use a frivolous cliche, but it appears to me that what we are discussing here is the shifting of the goalposts.
I suggest that the well‐respected political journalist Crispin Hull might well have supplied the answer in an article he wrote for the Canberra Times in October. Mr Hull said:
Northern Territory government sources say the Keating Government was lobbied by both sides in the euthanasia debate.
One side wanted it to use the Commonwealth Government's veto power and the other wanted it to allow the Northern Territory's law to stand.

It seems that the anti‐euthanasia forces realised that the option of veto by the executive looked a bit heavy‐handed and that it might be better to push for some Christian Right MPs to propose a private members bill based on the Commonwealth's over‐riding constitutional power to make laws for the territories on any subject whatever . . .—the very power which was used to give the Northern Territory self‐government in the first place.

I do believe that this attack on our democracy has been overlooked by those whose primary concern is the matter of euthanasia itself. This is an extremely emotive issue, and one which strikes at the core of our personal safety. But with the Andrews bill we are telling the people of the Northern Territory that the conventions of representative democracy do not always apply. Yes, the Commonwealth government can interfere when the proper exercise of power by another legislature is in question, but this has not happened in Australia's history. So how can we expect the people of this nation to continue to give us their trust if we choose to take such unprecedented action?

What we have not discussed at length is the fact that this overriding constitutional power was designed only to be used in cases of riot or civil unrest. The strength of our democracy is that one member of parliament can introduce a bill which allows for public and parliamentary debate. That right is sacrosanct and should not be eroded. But I also believe that if federal MPs get into the habit of overturning territory legislation each time it conflicts with their own beliefs, they mock the very process of democracy.

I do not believe we have given enough thought to the moves being made by this bill and the ongoing effect when one parliament attempts to override the decisions of another parliament. Are we fully conversant, for a start, with the effects Commonwealth intervention would have on the operation of criminal law in the Northern Territory? I do not believe so. Some of the best criminal and constitutional lawyers in this country are undecided on the matter. We must remember that the Andrews bill has wider ramifications in that the Australian Capital Territory and Norfolk Island are also affected by it. It can be fairly presented that this bill is anti‐democratic in relation to the territories.

BREAK.PARA: I believe the people of this nation have the reasonable expectation that what we say is what we do. I do not believe we can ignore the fact that the Northern Territory was granted self‐government in 1978. I do not believe this government can debate the Andrews bill as though the Northern Territory government has no relevance. I do not believe we should continue the debate on euthanasia until the aspect of Commonwealth rights in the matter of the Northern Territory has been clearly addressed and resolved. To do so would be politically and morally unthinkable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to participate in the debate on the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 I want to say at the outset that there are many people of good conscience all over this country—indeed, in my own electorate—who have differing views on this very important issue. I believe that this piece of legislation is just as important as any economic bills before this parliament as it deals with society values. I believe those who support euthanasia do so legitimately and fervently, with compassion for those who suffer in their dying days or in times of great physical and perhaps mental stress. I believe they are compassionate people and they believe that the Northern Territory bill is a proper way to address this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I have considered very strongly how I would vote on this issue and how I would address the issue. I have to say that, in my own conscience, there is no way that I could ever support active euthanasia. Instead of looking for ways in which to assist the frail and ill in our community to end their lives, we should rather be exploring ways of improving their quality of life. In this context, that includes finding additional resources for palliative care and all that it can do for those who are suffering.

I believe strongly and always have in the sanctity of life. I maintain that we lack secure limits on voluntary euthanasia, and I ask which group of people would be next in line for inclusion. Will we include those born with disabilities or other impairments when we ask society to allow others to kill people? The fact of legal euthanasia creates additional pressures for those already feeling vulnerable: the elderly, frail, lonely, ill and those suffering depression or anxiety. The Hippocratic oath requires medical professionals to preserve life and relieve pain and suffering and it has never ever condoned the taking of life. We have a need to provide greater community support in the palliative care area to allow people greater choice about how they are cared for in their last days to improve the quality of life, not death. I am not persuaded as to the efficacy of the proposed safeguards in the Northern Territory legislation. Dr Peter Baume, in his article in Australian Medicine on 15 January 1996, in arguing the case for euthanasia admitted that:

Difficulty arises sometimes in knowing who is making the request for euthanasia while competent, who is no longer competent, who is suffering from treatable depression, and who might make a different request at a different time.

Euthanasia is another word for state sanctioned killing. In a country where we do not support capital punishment for the most heinous crimes, the Northern Territory has introduced legislation that allows for the state sanctioned killing of those in our society who are most vulnerable.
Comments made by Father John Brosnan, the prison chaplain to Ronald Ryan, the last man to be hanged in Australia, included these:

You know what state sanctioned killing did to Ronald Ryan or, in the case of euthanasia, what it would do to the patient. However, we rarely consider what an involvement in state sanctioned killing does to the rest of us. If someone believes their life has become worthless because of community prejudice, loneliness or inadequate physical or emotional care then the job of the community is to improve the person's life, not destroy it. Allowing the problem to be addressed by killing the person allows society to avoid having to take the harder and more expensive road of actually providing resources for a more supportive, interesting and caring way of life for those who have lost hope.

A sense of hopelessness or worthlessness is not something to be accepted or admired as an expression of autonomy. There may be a cry for help or a demand for new efforts for those who care about the person. Killing the person with the problem is not the way to solve the problem. We all acknowledge that, with all the safeguards, checks and balances of the legal system conducted in a public forum, innocent people will still be killed and have been in this regard in capital punishment. There may not be many but there will certainly be some. How then can anyone pretend that innocent people will not be killed in a system where a couple of doctors have to agree behind closed doors?
With most legal rules, even the most disastrous mistakes can usually be addressed in one way or another. With capital punishment and euthanasia, every mistake is permanent. There is no turning back.

The deleterious effect of suicide on a victim's close friends and family is well documented. There are no guarantees or safeguards to ensure that close friends and families of a state sanctioned killing will not also be traumatised by that death. I can understand that many might feel a genuine sense of relief at the cessation of suffering of the terminally ill and dying and the capacity to be with them at the end because the time and date can be arranged, so to speak. But when that initial sense of relief wears off and the grieving process proceeds, it is possible that there might develop a sense of guilt and questions arise as to whether or not all options of palliative care were taken.

There is a difference between rejecting futile life‐prolonging treatment and actively assisting someone to die. Doctors who provide the means of ending a person's life, but who take no active role in the administration of, for example, a lethal injection, are in practice assisting in state sanctioned killing. An article in the Australian Disability Review No. 2, 1996 made the following comment. It said:
The paper concludes that such legislation (legalised euthanasia) could create a social climate in which people with disability may actually be required to justify their very right to exist.

The states and territories have rights to make laws for their citizens but there is, in this instance, an overriding national interest. The Northern Territory legislation, in effect, has changed the law on euthanasia for all Australians, not just territorians.

I do understand that there are many differing views on this issue. There are differing views in my electorate. There are differing views throughout Australia and across society. This Northern Territory legislation is, to the best of my knowledge, the first legislation in the world to allow the medical profession to terminate life which it deems is no longer wanted by the individual who previously held it. While I agree with the right, and I believe in the sincerity of every member who has and will speak on this issue before our parliament, in all conscience, there is no way that I could support the Northern Territory legislation.
In a letter to me—and I assume in a similar letter to other members and senators—Colleen McCullough, the well‐known Australian novelist, wrote, amongst other things:

I have to say that prudence, commonsense and a considerable experience of human nature dispose me to think that euthanasia is an unattainable, if humane, dream. It wouldn't work because it couldn't work. I wish it could.

Like Colleen McCullough, I wish, for the benefit of all those suffering people whom I have spent dying hours with, that it could work. But I believe that it will not, and I will be supporting the Andrews bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bailey, Fran, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —While this bill, the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, does seek to use the Commonwealth's constitutional powers to override a law of the Northern Territory, this debate, both in this place and outside in the wider community, is really about the right of Australian citizens to active euthanasia. The debate on this issue within our national parliament is undoubtedly as divided as the debate in our local communities.

SPEECH.PARA: What this bill is designed to achieve is to overturn the intent of the Northern Territory legislation. The intent of that Northern Territory legislation is to allow people to make a conscious decision to end their lives. It is not to provide a legal framework that will allow medical practitioners the right to relieve pain and suffering, even if, in doing so, that action hastens the death of a patient. It goes that step further. It crosses a threshold that I feel uneasy and uncomfortable with. It actually provides a legal framework for a patient to request, albeit with a level of counselling and consultation, to terminate his or her life by administering a lethal injection. This process is, I believe, active euthanasia, or perhaps more correctly should be called `assisted suicide'.

I have great sympathy and empathy for anyone suffering the debilitating and dehumanising effects of a terminal illness. In fact, I watched my father, who died almost two years ago to the day, after being diagnosed with bone cancer. I saw how that disease affected his life and that of my mother. I watched as the disease progressed, resulting in an amputation of one leg. I watched how my father had to learn to walk again with the aid of an artificial limb—an extremely difficult exercise for such a very large, tall man. He had been a very active man, used to playing golf at least three times a week.

I watched as my mother's life changed as she took on the role of a full‐time carer. There were times, especially in the latter stages of my father's illness, when it was difficult to adjust the level and mix of medication required to keep the pain under control as the disease progressed. It is this method of treatment that I believe, as legislators, we should be concentrating our time and effort on—that is, improving the standard of and access to palliative care.

I will always be grateful to the nurses of the district nursing service who daily visited and cared for my father and, especially in the last week of my father's life, for the loving care and dedication of his doctor and the nursing staff of the Buderim Hospital in which he spent his final week. My family are indebted to them because they ensured that my father received the appropriate level and type of medication needed to keep his increasing level of pain under control.

There are some who might describe this method of pain management as passive euthanasia. However, I will always be grateful that my father—and countless numbers of others in the same position as my father—was able to die peacefully and with dignity. This method of pain management and dying with dignity is not what the Northern Territory legislation is designed to achieve. Instead, it is designed to allow a person deliberately to end their life by self‐administering a lethal injection. I cannot support that.

Like all who have spoken in this debate, I too have read and consulted widely on this issue. I have to say that I have found no better expression of my beliefs or feelings than the words of Sir Gustav Nossal, who said:

Dying with dignity and in peace should be everyone's right, particularly in an industrialised country with high standards of health care. Nevertheless, I am against the formal legislation of euthanasia. A well‐ordered society is a very fragile thing, as recent history (Hitler, Pol Pot, Rwanda) shows. I believe there are grave dangers in a society giving to anyone, no matter how well intentioned, the right to terminate a human life. However, I do believe that those who are terminally ill should come to the end as free of pain as possible and with as tranquil a state of mind as possible. This may necessitate the use of strong drugs in doses that imperil life. I certainly do not believe that fear of possibly fatal consequences should limit the dosage of narcotics, tranquillisers or other medications in such circumstances. It seems to me that the crucial thing here is intent. The intent to relieve pain and suffering is good; the intent directly to kill breaches what I consider to be societal norms. Enshrining a right to terminate life in legislation would, I believe, do more harm than good, although I totally support the right of others to disagree with this view.
I heartily concur with the words of Sir Gustav Nossal, and I support this bill.
In conclusion, I would like to place on the record my appreciation to all those from my electorate who have taken the time and effort to make their views known to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mutch, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Euthanasia Laws Bill that has been proposed by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews). In doing so I note that the debate has gone on for a long time and that there has been a great deal of learned discussion.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill seeks to amend the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978, the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 and the Norfolk Island Act 1979. The purpose of the bill is to ensure that the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly and the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly do not have the power to make laws which would permit that form of intentional killing of another—called euthanasia—which includes mercy killing, or the assisting of another person to terminate his or her own life.

I come to this debate with the general view which I have always held that I am opposed to the principle of taking the life of another. Obviously, there are examples when this occurs such as in just wars. There are also cases overseas where lives are taken in the course of capital punishment which is ordained by law. I see those situations in terms of self-defence but when it comes to the intentional taking of someone's life, whether they ask for that or not, I demur.

It seems to me that those who support the principle of euthanasia always qualify it and they are very rigid in the way they wish to qualify it. They are very concerned to make sure, because a lot of them are very decent, thinking people, that they are doing the right thing as well. They are always quick to point out that it must be voluntary, that it must be a completely free choice, and that it must be with complete consent or informed consent. They also are keen to insist that this would apply only to those in terrible need, to those who have a terrible need to end their suffering.

Maybe this is a simple view but it seems to me that there is a catch 22 involved in this situation. From my memory of Catch 22, that was a situation where people who were serving in a war wanted to get out of it because of the danger. They would go along to the doctor and say, `I am mad and therefore I should be relieved of my duties'. The doctor would always reply, `If you come to me and say that you are mad and you want to be relieved of your duties then you are obviously very sane indeed. Therefore, I will not accept your application'. They were caught.

In the case of euthanasia it seems to me that there is a parallel. There is a catch 22. We want to make sure that people who are asking to die do so with full and informed consent and yet we are applying the law to those people who cannot exercise full and informed consent. An example of this might be AIDS dementia. Basically, the Northern Territory legislation is a catch 22 situation. The Northern Territory legislation says that a patient must be suffering from an illness that in the normal course of events, without the application of extraordinary measures of treatment, will result in death. A psychiatrist must confirm the absence of any treatable clinical depression in respect of the illness but it must be causing severe pain and suffering.

The legislation also says that the patient must be of sound mind. It is always very difficult for someone to determine who else is of sound mind. I would have thought that someone who is in terrific pain and suffering and who wanted to end their life because of this pain and suffering is not really in a situation where they can make an informed decision. It seems to defeat itself. They cannot live to regret their decision if they have taken that decision. I would demur on the side of caution.

I also think it is wrong to change the onus of proof with respect to the medical profession. We all have these experiences. My grandmother was 101 and she was in a nursing home. We took her out at one stage when she wanted to come home but then she wanted to go back. She kept telling us how she was getting better but unfortunately there was never going to be a cure for old age. The one thing that she always feared was the thought, `They do not want me any longer. I am too old and they do not want me'. I felt that if those people walking around in white coats were authorised to give a lethal injection it would have been more of a strain upon her in that circumstance. It is always better for people in that situation to think that the people who are caring for them have their interests at heart. I would hate to see a situation develop where that was to change.

Like all other members, I have received lots and lots of representations on this issue, most of them opposing the concept of euthanasia but, of course, many supporting the concept of euthanasia. Some have written to me saying that, as the member for Cook, I am duty‐bound to do as they bid and to exercise their order and vote for euthanasia. But the truth is that if I were going to take that balancing exercise and either weigh the letters or count them, there would be far more letters opposing euthanasia.

If you did a poll of the electorate, I suppose, if people were not confused, it would be interesting to see what the result would be. I think that quite a lot of people think that turning the machine off is euthanasia, when it is nothing of the sort. In fact, as regards applying pain‐killing relief, I think sometimes the injections of morphine can be the terminally ill patient's best friend, if it takes them to a position where quite often people might die from pneumonia. I think that the people administering pain‐killing medication who get to the stage where that medication serves to hasten the end of the person can really act in good conscience in doing so. I think there is a world of difference between trying to relieve suffering and trying to end suffering by taking people into another state—the state of death.

There has been some concern about the role of this parliament and its ability to make legislation of this type. We have had representations, petitions, pleas and all sorts of other things from, for instance, Norfolk Island—I have got one here from the government of Norfolk Island. There have also been representations made by the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) and from the Northern Territory government. Much has been made of the role of those legislatures to govern for the peace, welfare and good government of the people under their jurisdiction, but I have a simple view about this as well: I think that governments have to play to the whistle, the way we do in sporting contests. If this government has the power to enact this legislation, so be it. If we do not have the power, let the High Court decide. So my view is that, if we can do it and we feel obliged to do it, we have every right to do so. That is my simple view of the matter.

I have also received another representation from Norfolk Island from none other than Colleen McCullough. I think all members have received a letter from Colleen McCullough. I was very impressed with her views on euthanasia, taking them not from a religious point of view, but I think from the point of view of someone who has a great deal of sympathy and has worked in the very sad areas where people have been severely retarded, or where people have suffered severe illnesses, and terminal illnesses in many cases. I do commend to people her paper which she delivered to the New South Wales parliament entitled Euthanasia: putting people down and I would like to subscribe to what she said in that paper. She makes the point that those who genuinely want to die will find a way to suicide without assistance. There can be great debate about this, and people who might be handicapped would find it very difficult to do so. It is not a simple question. She says also:

. . . but I believe that those who ask others to kill them do not genuinely want to die, for to ask someone else to do the unthinkable in the name of mercy and compassion is to shift the burden of responsibility to other shoulders and to invite another person to bear the guilt.
It is an interesting point that she makes. I think there is a glimmer of truth in that. I think it is very hard for people who have that expectation put upon them. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill is bad law. I think it is ridiculous that we come into a parliament and we introduce selectively a piece of legislation which does not address the question, but addresses self‐government and the powers exercised under the present legislation providing self‐government for the Australian territories. I say that on the premise that I am totally opposed to euthanasia. I say it on the basis that we are part of a federal system. If we had wanted to address the federal system, then we could do so. If we want to provide legislation which would analyse and detail the powers which we think should be available for the Commonwealth on social and other issues, we can do so by referendum. This could well be a bill which came in to call for a referendum of the Australian people to determine whether or not the Commonwealth government should have powers with respect to a range of social issues. In this instance, it might be in respect of euthanasia. It might be one that extends to abortion. It might be one that extends to a whole range of other social issues.

SPEECH.PARA: It is for that reason that I find it incredible that we have got a private member's bill that does all the wrong things. It comes into this parliament and tries to do something which frankly is discriminatory in the extreme and which prejudices the extent of what I see as the natural evolution of the power for the territories of Australia to be in the same position as every other Australian jurisdiction.

We have spent a fair bit of time in the last few weeks worrying about the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) who has produced a debate about racism. This is just as discriminatory. We have a whole lot of Australian citizens. If you come from a territory, you are just as much an Australian as if you come from New South Wales. Why should you be lesser creatures? This bill says that we are discriminating per se against everybody who lives in a territory. It does not say that it is going to deal against euthanasia for those who live in the states, so they are somehow going to be different.

I happen to be totally opposed to euthanasia. I think that one life unnecessarily taken is one life too many, but I am appalled when bad legislation is given the status—because it has been allowed to take a prominent place on the agenda of the parliament—of being tantamount to government legislation. As a member of the government, I do not think it should have that status. I think it would have been far better if it had been treated as is every other piece of legislation that is introduced by a private member and had taken its turn in the discussion on private members' day. I say that because we are not voting on euthanasia in this bill. I have heard, with a great deal of respect, the views expressed by my colleague, the honourable member for Cook (Mr Mutch) and I have listened to a number of other contributions.

The point is we are not talking about euthanasia. We are talking about the powers that this Commonwealth should exercise selectively to discriminate against a few Australians. I think it is bad law to be discriminating against a few Australians. I am against racism. I do not agree with the prejudices that have emerged from some of the views expressed by the honourable member for Oxley. I certainly do not think that we can say—because we produce a piece of legislation that looks particularly at self‐government—that we are talking about the question itself. It worries me that a device has been chosen to wheel around a very significant issue. I would have far preferred that we had come into this parliament and, if opposed to euthanasia, we had said, `We're going to introduce a bill which says that we are going to ensure that no law pertaining to euthanasia can be produced in Australia.' That is what this bill should be doing. This bill is a device. It does not achieve what those who are advocates against euthanasia believe. It does not achieve what those who might be pro‐euthanasia believe it is going to do. All it does is selectively apply in those territories that have been identified under schedules 1, 2 and 3, and it is not going to apply to anybody else. I think that if we are going to be honest with ourselves, we should not introduce discriminatory law against Australians. That concerns me greatly.

There are a whole lot of other aspects of the detail that worry me, but in the time you have in this place, you cannot really talk about the great detail.
